tgt_text.0: THE author of the celebrated romance of " THE GOLDEN Ass" lived in the early part of the second century, under the Antonines.
tgt_text.1: By most modern biographers he is called Lucius Apuleius, or Appuleius, but the authority on which they assign him that præ­ nomen is very questionable.
tgt_text.2: He was a native of Madaura, an inland African town, and he styles himself, in allusion to its po­ sition on the borders of two kingdoms, " a half-and-half Numi- than and Getulian;
tgt_text.3: " adding that, in that respect, he resembled the elder Cyrus, who was " a Semi-Median and Semi.Persian."
tgt_text.4: Madaura, after having formed part of the kingdom of Syphax.
tgt_text.5: was bestowed by the Romans on their ally Masinissa, and being eventually resumed and peopled by veterans, it obtained the rank and immunities of a " colony," and rose to considerable splendour.
tgt_text.6: The father of Apuleius filled the office of duumvir, the highest magisterial dignity in his native place, and bequeathed at his death the sum of nearly two millions of sesterces to his two sons, one of whom, the subject of our present inquiries, succeeded to his office.
tgt_text.7: These facts we learn from the direct testimony of the son in his Apologia or Defence ;
tgt_text.8: but most of the biographers of Apuleius add other particulars, drawn from the assumption that, under the character of Lucius, the imagi­ nary hero of the story of "the Golden Ass," the author has related sundry details of his own personal history.
tgt_text.9: Upon this supposition, we are told that our author's prænomen was Lucius, that his father's name was Theseus, his mother's Salvia, and that she was of a Thessalian family, and descended from the illustrious Plutarch;
tgt_text.10: furthermore, that Apuleius was ignorant of the Latin language until he visited Rome.
tgt_text.11: where he acquired it without the aid of a master;
tgt_text.12: and that by the time he arrived at the capital of the empire, he had so completely dissipated his patrimony, as to be under the necessity of selling his clothes, in order to defray the cost of his initiation into the mysteries of Osiris.
tgt_text.13: This latter statement is at variance with the account which he gives of his fortune in the Apologia, where he says, merely, that it had been, " modice imminutum," somewhat im.
tgt_text.15: the other particulars may or may not be true.
tgt_text.16: There is, no doubt, such a 'resemblance between Apuleius and Lucius, both as regards mental characteristics and outward incidents, that we can hardly suppose it to be fortuitous.
tgt_text.17: It is highly probable that the author drew his hero from his own likeness;
tgt_text.18: but on the other hand, it is absurd to look for literal fidelity in such a por­ trait.
tgt_text.19: It is not likely, for instance, that Apuleius would have deemed it consistent with decorum to speak of himself, his father and his mother, by their real names, in so frolicsome a work of fiction as " The Golden Ass," since we find, that when addressing the sons of a friend in some complimentary verses of a peculiar character, such as the habits of his day allowed, he thought it his duty to invent pseudonymes for the objects of his flattery.
tgt_text.20: *Apuleius received the first rudiments of education at Carthage, renowned at that time as a school of literature, and there he adopted the Platonic system of philosophy, in which he perfected himself by his subsequent studies at Athens.
tgt_text.21: There, too, he laid the foundations of that copious stock of various and profound learning, through which he became the most distinguished lite­ rary character of his age.
tgt_text.22: Still thirsting for knowledge, and impelled, like his own Lucius, by an insatiable curiosity to ex­ plore all that was hidden from the vulgar gaze, he travelled through Greece, Asia, and Italy, and became a member of many religious fraternities, and a proficient in their mys­ teries.
tgt_text.23: After his return to Africa, he was about to renew his travels, and on his way to Alexandria was taken ill at Oëa, a maritime town, which some geographers have identified with the modern Tripoli.
tgt_text.24: A young man, named Pontianus, whom he had known as a fellow-student at Athens, invited the invalid to become the guest of his mother, a wealthy widow, named Pudentilla.
tgt_text.25: In making this hospitable proposal, Pontianus had more in view than the comfort of his friend, and the restoration of his health.
tgt_text.26: Pudentilla was herself also an invalid, being affected with a chronic complaint, which had lasted thir­ teen years-the duration of her widowhood-and for which her medical advisers all agreed in prescribing marriage as a remedy.
tgt_text.27: The son, seeing his mother prepared to try the effect of that nostrum, was desirous that her new husband should be one of his own choosing.
tgt_text.28: Accordingly, he begged Apuleius would do him the favour to become his stepfather, putting the affair to him, says the latter, in the light of an onerous service, such as one might ask a friend and a philosopher to undertake.
tgt_text.29: The widow was neither young nor handsome, but she was virtuous, fond, and very rich.
tgt_text.30: Apuleius, if not poor, was, at least, reduced in circumstances, in consequence of his long-continued course of study, his protracted residence in foreign countries, and various acts of generosity towards his friends and instructors ;
tgt_text.32: so in fine he married the widow.
tgt_text.33: But this act involved some unpleasant consequences.
tgt_text.34: Before it was accomplished, Pontianus had married the daughter of one Rufinus, who, long eager to secure to his son-in-law as large a share as possible in the fortune of Pudentilla, did all he could to prevent her marriage with Apuleius;
tgt_text.35: and in this he was seconded by Pontianus, over whom he had acquired such an influence, as to make him look with aversion on the suc­ cess of his own project.
tgt_text.36: But not with standing all opposition, Pudentilla persisted in her resolution ;
tgt_text.37: and soon after her mar­ riage, Pontianus died.
tgt_text.38: His uncle, AEmilianus, then united with Rufinus in endeavours to ruin Apuleius.
tgt_text.39: They gave out that he had poisoned Pontianus, that he was a magician, and had gained the affections of Pudentilla by witcheraft.
tgt_text.40: They even prosecuted him upon the latter charge, and the cause was tried at Sabrata, before Claudius Maximus, the proconsul of Africa.
tgt_text.41: It was on that occasion he delivered the Defence, a translation of which will be found in this volume.
tgt_text.42: It is a clever and amusing per formance, having nothing of the tragic earnestness of a man who is pleading for his life;
tgt_text.43: on the-contrary, Apuleius appears, from first to last, to have felt quite secure as to the issue, and to have flung himself with great glee into a contest which afforded him such capital opportunities for displaying his wit, his learning, and his powers of rhetoric.
tgt_text.44: His adversaries had a bad game to play;
tgt_text.45: they played it into his hands, and he made good use of their blun­ ders.
tgt_text.46: The main charge was ridiculous enough, and Apuleius had for it a ready and sufficient answer :
tgt_text.48: You are surprised," he said, " that a woman should have married again after thirteen years of widowhood;
tgt_text.49: but the real wonder is, that she should have remained unmarried so long.
tgt_text.50: You pretend that magic alone could have forced a widow of her years to marry a young man ;
tgt_text.51: but that is just the sort of case in which magic would be quite superfluous."
tgt_text.52: As if to give the more force to this argument, the prosecutors were indiscreet enough to lay great stress on the graces and ac­ complishments of the accused, and to press upon the notice of the court that Apuleius was altogether such a man as was most likely, in the natural course of things, to find favour in a woman's eyes;
tgt_text.53: for he was handsome, and not negligent of his person ;
tgt_text.57: and this handsome man, who cultivated cleanliness as well as phi­ losophy, had a ready wit and a fluent tongue!
tgt_text.58: After the discomfiture of his wife's relations, it seems probable that nothing very remarkable occurred to disturb the even tenour of a life of literary labour to which Apuleius devoted himself.
tgt_text.59: All that is known of this latter part of his career, is, that he was a most voluminous writer;
tgt_text.60: that he frequently declaimed in public with great applause;
tgt_text.61: he was a priest of Æsculapius, the pa­ tron god of Carthage;
tgt_text.62: he had the charge of exhibiting gladi­ atorial shows and wild beast hunts in the province, and statues were erected in his honour by the senate of Carthage and of other states.
tgt_text.63: It was probably in his latter days that he composed his most celebrated work, " The Metamorphoses, or the Golden Ass for neither does he allude to it in those passages in which he boasts of the extent and variety of his literary productions ;
tgt_text.64: nor was any mention made of it upon the occasion of his trial for magic, as would certainly have been done had his prosecutors been aware of the existence of such a book.
tgt_text.65: This celebrated romance pur­ ports to be the autobiography of a certain Lucius of Madaura, whose curiosity with respect to magic.
tgt_text.66: has been rewarded by his tranformation into the form of a jackass, in which he undergoes many curious and ludicrous adventures, until he is at last restored to human shape by the interposition of the goddess Isis, to whose service he devotes himself.

tgt_text.1102: At length, having lightened us of all our burden, they turned us into the next meadow, to graze as we pleased.
tgt_text.1103: My sense of conviviality, however, was not sufficient to keep me in the company of the ass, or of my horse, especially as I was not habituated to making my dinner upon grass.
tgt_text.1104: But as I was now perishing with hunger, I boldly effected an entrance into a little garden I caught sight of, behind the stable, and ate my bellyful of the vegetables, raw as they were.
tgt_text.1105: Then invoking all the gods, I looked about in every quarter to see if by chance I might any where espy in the neighbouring gar­ dens a rose-tree in full bloom.
tgt_text.1106: For the solitude of the spot, its distance from the public road, and the fruit trees that con­ cealed it, now afforded me great hopes, that if, on taking the remedy, I should quit the grovelling gait of a four-footed beast of burden and become erect again, in the shape of a man, I might do so, unobserved by any body.
tgt_text.1107: Whilst, then, I was fluctuating amid this sea of contempla­ tion, I beheld, a little further on, a dell shaded by a leafy grove;
tgt_text.1108: and among its various plants and delightful foliage, shone the vermilion tint of blooming roses.
tgt_text.1109: In my imagina­ tion, which was not entirely that of a brute, I pictured this to myself as the grove of Venus and the Graces;
tgt_text.1110: among whose shady recesses, the regal splendour of that genial flower was brilliantly glowing.
tgt_text.1111: So, invoking Prosperous Event, * I ran with such speed, that, by Hercules!
tgt_text.1112: I fancied myself no longer an ass, but an exceedingly swift racer of the circus.
tgt_text.1113: Still this remarkable effort of activity was unable to outstrip my evil fortune.
tgt_text.1114: For when I had now arrived at the spot, I no longer saw those fresh and charming roses, wet with divine dews and with nectar, which happy brambles and thrice-blessed thorns produce, nor, indeed, any dell whatever, but only the margin of a river's bank, planted with thickset trees.
tgt_text.1115: These trees had long leaves like those of the laurel, and bore a sort of inodorous blossom of a cup-like form and red colour.
tgt_text.1116: These scentless flowers the ignorant common people call, in their rural vocabulary, rose-laurels, to eat which is sure death to all cattle.
tgt_text.1117: Finding myself ensnared by such a fatality, and casting aside all regard for safety, I determined voluntarily to eat of these envenomed roses.
tgt_text.1118: But, while I was hesitatingly ap­ proaching in order to pluck them, a young fellow, the very gardener, as I saw, whose vegetables I had so shockingly laid waste, perceiving the loss he had sustained, ran furiously at me with a great stick in his hand, and having caught me, belaboured me so, that I should have been in danger of losing my life, had I not at last had the wisdom to take my own part.
tgt_text.1119: For throwing up my rump, I struck out at him rapidly and repeatedly with my hind feet, and having severely punished him, and laid him prostrate against a bank on the mountain's side, sought safety in flight.
tgt_text.1120: Instantly, however, a certain woman, his wife, I suppose, catching sight of him from an elevated spot, as he lay prostrate and half dead, flew towards him, with shrieks and yells, evi- dently on purpose, that by her lamentations she might be the occasion of my instant destruction.
tgt_text.1121: For all the villagers, being aroused by her screams, straightway called out their dogs, and from.
tgt_text.1122: all quarters hounded them on, in order that, exasperated by fury, they might rush upon me and tear me in pieces.
tgt_text.1123: I made no doubt whatever but that I was on the brink of death when I saw the dogs, very large ones too, and many in number, and fit to fight with bears and lions, rushing furiously against me from all quarters.
tgt_text.1124: Adopting, therefore, what seemed my only chance, I gave up all thoughts of flight, and galloped back to the inn at which we had put up.
tgt_text.1125: But the country people keeping off the dogs with much difficulty, seized and bound me with a very stout thong of leather to a staple, and would no doubt have beat me to death, had it not been that my stomach, compressed by the pain of the blows, and disordered by those raw vegetables with which it was stuffed, squirted out its contents, and drove away my persecutors from my aching sides, besprinkling some of them with the most abo­ minable liquid, and choking others with the stench.'
tgt_text.1126: Not long afterwards, as the sun was now declining from the meridian, the robbers again led us forth from the stable heavily laden, myself especially, whose burden was far heavier than that of the rest.
tgt_text.1127: We had now completed a good part of the journey;
tgt_text.1128: I was exhausted by its length and the weight of my burden, sore from the cudgelling I had got, and lame and staggering from my hoofs being quite worn to the quick;
tgt_text.1129: so, as I was passing along the winding course of a gently flowing rivulet, I was thinking that I would cunningly seize that excellent oppor­ tunity, and lie down, bending my legs under me, fully deter­ mined not to rise from the spot, whatever blows might be in­ flicted on me;
tgt_text.1130: ay, ready even, not only to be beaten with a stick, but pierced with a sword, rather than budge.
tgt_text.1131: For I imagined that being now fully half dead and exhausted, I should receive an honourable discharge,* on account of bodily infirmity:
tgt_text.1132: or, that at least the robbers, irritated at the delay, and desirous of hastening their flight, would divide the load which I carried on my back between the two other beasts of burden, and that, by way of a still more severe revenge, they would leave me a prey to the wolves and vultures.
tgt_text.1133: My most cruel destiny, however, thwarted the execution of so admirable a plan.
tgt_text.1134: For that other ass, divining and antici­ pating my intention, immediately pretended to be overcome with fatigue, and fell sprawling on the ground with all his bag­ gage, and lying as if he was dead, made no attempt to rise for all their whacking or goading, no, nor even when they tried to pull him up on all sides by the tail, the ears, and the legs.
tgt_text.1135: At last the robbers grew tired of the hopeless job, and having conferred together, they resolved that their flight should not be further retarded by wasting time upon an ass that was a,,;
tgt_text.1137: So, having divided his load between me and the horse, and drawing a sword, they cut both his ham­ strings ;
tgt_text.1138: then they dragged him, still breathing, a little out of the public road, and threw him down a very lofty precipice into the valley below.
tgt_text.1139: Then, indeed, taking warning by the destiny of my unfortunate comrade, I determined to lay aside all tricks and stratagems, and prove myself to my masters to be a diligent, deserving ass.
tgt_text.1140: Besides, I had heard them say to each other, that we should soon come to a stop, and make an end of our journey and our toils, for yonder was the place pf their abode.
tgt_text.1141: At length, having passed a little hill of easy ascent, we ar­ rived at the place of our destination.
tgt_text.1142: All the things were un­ packed and stowed away indoors;
tgt_text.1143: and being now relieved from my burden, I took a refreshing roll in the dust in lieu of a bath.
tgt_text.1144: The occasion itself, as well as the nature of my story, demands that I should here give a description of the locality and of the cave in which the robbers dwelt.
tgt_text.1145: For thus I shall make trial of my own abilities, and at the same time enable you to judge if I was an ass in sense and understanding as well as in form.
tgt_text.1146: It was a rugged mountain, covered with dark forests, and of extraordinary height.
tgt_text.1147: Winding athwart its declivity, flanked by steep, inaccessible rocks, ran deep and intricate gullies, choked with brambles, and thus affording a natural defence.
tgt_text.1148: A spring burst forth from the summit of the mountain in great bubbling gushes, and rolling its silvery waters down the steeps, parted into a number of rivulets, formed pools in the valleys, and encompassed the base of the mountain with large sheets of standing water.
tgt_text.1149: On the rock, over the mouth of the cavern, there was a sort of fort, constructed with strong posts and hur- dies, enclosing a space well suited for penning sheep.
tgt_text.1150: Before the door there were small shrubs * extending along in place of a wall, and this enclosure you may fairly denominate, on my authority, the robbers' receiving room.
tgt_text.1151: There was no other edifice in the place, except a small hut roughly covered with reeds;
tgt_text.1152: in which sentinels, selected by lot from the band of robbers, as I afterwards learned, kept watch by night.
tgt_text.1153: Leaving us secured by a stout leather thong before the door, they crept into the cave, one after another, with their limbs squeezed together, and bawled angrily to an old woman, who, though bent with age, seemed to be entrusted with the entire charge of so many young men."
tgt_text.1155: you old corpse, whom Life is ashamed to own, and Death scorns, do you mean to make game of us, sitting idly at home, and not providing a supper to comfort us at this late hour, after all our toil and peril ?
tgt_text.1156: You who do nothing day and night but swill down wine into that craving stomach of yours.
tgt_text.1158: "Nay, now," the frightened and trembling old woman squeaked out, “ nay, now, my brave and honourable young masters, there is plenty of nice stewed meat of all kinds, loaves in abundance, wine without stint, in polished cups, and warm water ready as usual for your hasty bath."
tgt_text.1159: When she had said this, they immediately undressed, and standing naked be­ fore a great fire, sluiced themselves with hot water, anointed themselves with oil, and then went and reclined at a table abundantly supplied with dishes.
tgt_text.1160: Hardly had they taken their places, when another and much more numerous party of young men entered, whom you would without hesitation have taken to be robbers also;
tgt_text.1161: for they, too, brought with them booty in the shape of gold and silver money, drinking vessels, and silken garments embroidered with threads of gold.
tgt_text.1162: The new-comers having likewise refreshed themselves by bathing, joined their comrades;
tgt_text.1163: and some who were chosen by lot waited upon the rest.
tgt_text.1164: They ato and drank in a most disorderly manner, with meat piled up in heaps, bread in hil- locks, and tankards ranged in whole platoons upon the board.
tgt_text.1165: They were obstreperous in their mirth, sang as loud as they could bawl, exchanged scurrilous jokes, and behaved in all respects like Theban Lapithæ,* or half-brute Centaurs.
tgt_text.1166: At last the burliest among them all thus addressed the rest:
tgt_text.1167: -" Right bravely have we ransacked that house of Milo, at Hypata!
tgt_text.1168: And besides the vast booty we gained by our prowess, we have brought back our full number to camp, safe and sound, with an increase, too, of eight feet,† if that is worth men­ tioning.
tgt_text.1169: But you, who have been pillaging the cities of Boeotia, have brought back thinned numbers, having lost that bravest of leaders, Lamachus, whose safety I should certainly have preferred, and with good reason, to all these packages you have brought home.
tgt_text.1170: Be that as it may, it was his own excess of bravery that was his destruction, and the memory of so great a hero will be celebrated among illustrious kings and leaders in battle.
tgt_text.1171: But as for you, who are very careful robbers, you do a trumpery trade ‡ in petty, dastardly thefts, sneaking timidly about baths, and old women's bits of houses.
tgt_text.1172: "To this, one of the new-comers replied, "You don't know,.
tgt_text.1173: then, what is notorious to everybody, that large houses are much the easiest to sack ?
tgt_text.1174: For though a great number of ser­ vants is kept in them, still each of these has more regard for his own safety than for his master's property.
tgt_text.1175: But people who lead a frugal and retired life, vigorously defend their little store, at the hazard of their lives:
tgt_text.1176: or else, if it is ample, they keep it, to say the least, pretty carefully concealed.
tgt_text.1177: And, in fact, the thing itself will verify what I have asserted.
tgt_text.1179: "No sooner had we arrived in the seven-gated city of Thebes, than we diligently made enquiries about the wealth of each of the citizens, that being always the first thing to be looked after by men of our profession :
tgt_text.1180: and so we came to hear of a certain banker, by name Chryseros, a man who possessed much money, but took great pains to conceal his vast wealth, lest he should be required to serve in public capacities.
tgt_text.1181: In fact, content with a small but remarkably well barred and bolted house, he lived there all alone, ragged and dirty, and brooded over his bags of gold."
tgt_text.1182: Accordingly, we agreed to pay our first visit to him;
tgt_text.1183: for, despising the resistance of a single pair of hands, we thought we should, without any difficulty, carry off all his wealth.
tgt_text.1184: Without delay, therefore, as soon as it was night, we met to­ gether before his gate;
tgt_text.1186: but as we did not think it prudent either to take it off its hinges, or force it open, much less to smash it, lest the noise of its two wings* should alarm all the neighbourhood, to our destruction, that magnanimous standard- bearer of ours, Lamachus, confident in his well-tried valour, gradually introduced his arm through an aperture made for the purpose of putting the key inside, and endeavoured to draw back the bolt.
tgt_text.1187: But Chryseros, that most villanous of all bipeds, having been on the watch all the time, and aware of all that was going on, crept softly to the door, preserving a profound silence, and with a sudden violent effort, fastened the hand of our leader, with a great nail, to a pannel of the gate.
tgt_text.1188: Then, leaving him transfixed, like a wretch on the cross, he ascended to the roof of his hovel, and shouted with all his might to his neighbours, calling to them by their respective names, and advising them to have regard for their- common safety, for.
tgt_text.1189: his house had caught fire unexpectedly.
tgt_text.1190: Accordingly, terrified by the proximity of the imminent danger, every one ran anxiously to render assistance."
tgt_text.1191: In this dilemma, on the point of being overwhelmed by numbers unless we deserted our comrade, we adopted, with his, own consent, a desperate remedy, suggested by the circum­ stances.
tgt_text.1192: For we cut off our leader's † arm by a blow right through the joint;
tgt_text.1193: and leaving it there, we bound up the stump with plenty of rags, lest the drops of blood might betray our track, and hastily carried off with us what remained of Lama­ chus.
tgt_text.1194: The whole neighbourhood was now alarmed, and pursued us with loud outcries;
tgt_text.1195: and we, in the fear of impending peril, quickened our flight, whilst he could neither keep up with- our swift pace, nor yet remain where he was with any safety.
tgt_text.1196: Then this most magnanimous and transcendently brave man besought us with all manner of prayers and entreaties, by the right hand of Mars, and by our mutual oaths, to rescue a brave comrade from torture and captivity.
tgt_text.1198: For how is it possible,' said he, ‘that a brave robber can survive the loss of his right hand, with which alone he can plunder and cut throats ?
tgt_text.1199: It would be happiness for him to meet a voluntary death by the hand of one of his comrades.
tgt_text.1200: As, however, he could not persuade any one of us, with all his entreaties, to commit a voluntary act of parricide, he drew his sword with his remaining hand, and after kissing it repeatedly, plunged it with a mighty stroke into the middle of his breast.
tgt_text.1201: Filled with veneration for the courage of our magnanimous leader, we carefully wrapped his mutilated dead body in a linen garment, and committed it to the sea,* there to find a place of concealment.
tgt_text.1202: And now does our Lamachust lie entombed, with the whole ocean for his burying-place, after having ended his life in a manner worthy of his heroic deeds.“
tgt_text.1203: And Alcimus likewise, with all his well-concerted enter­ prises, could not escape the sinister influence of fortune.
tgt_text.1204: He had broken into an old woman's cottage while she was asleep, and having ascended into an upper bedchamber, when he ought instantly to have strangled her, he thought proper first to throw all the things down to us, one by one, from the wide window, in order that we might make off with them.
tgt_text.1205: Having now cleared the room in a workmanlike manner, he had no mind to spare even the mattress on which the old woman slept;
tgt_text.1206: so, rolling her out of it, he was preparing to throw the coun­ terpane after the other things, when the' abominable old ag fell on her knees before him, crying:
tgt_text.1207: ‘ Why, my son, I be­ seech you, do you cast the poor and worn-out furniture of a most wretched old woman to my wealthy neighbours, upon whose house this window looks out ?'“
tgt_text.1208: Alcimus, deceived by these crafty words, and believing what she said to be true, was afraid that the things he had already thrown out, and those he was about to send after them, might, through his mistake, fall not into the hands of his associates, but into other people's houses;
tgt_text.1209: he therefore thrust his body out of the window, in order that he might make a judicious survey of the environs, and particularly that he might look with an eye to future business at that adjoining house she had mentioned.
tgt_text.1210: While, however, he was intent upon this, and quite careless of his own safety, that old miscreant took him unawares, as he leaned outwards, with his body balancing un­ steadily, and with a push which, though feeble, was sudden and unexpected, she pitched him out headlong.
tgt_text.1211: Besides falling from a great height, he dropped upon an enormous great stone which happened to lie near the house, so that he smashed all his ribs, and lay vomiting streams of blood, till, after he had first related* to us what had taken place, death put a speedy end to his torments
tgt_text.1212: Him also we buried in the same manner as our former leader, and sent him, as a worthy comrade, to follow Lamachus."
tgt_text.1213: Having thus suffered a double loss, we now abandoned our Theban enterprises, and departed for the next city, which is Plateæ.
tgt_text.1214: Here we heard a great deal of talk about a person named Demochares, who was about to exhibit a spectacle of gladiators.
tgt_text.1215: For, being a man of high birth, and distinguished for his great wealth and liberality, he catered for the public amusement with a splendour commensurate with his fortune.
tgt_text.1216: Where is the man with genius and eloquence enough to do- scribe, in appropriate words, all the various details of the manifold preparations?
tgt_text.1217: There were gladiators famous for dexterity of hand ;
tgt_text.1218: hunters of well-tried swiftness of foot;
tgt_text.1219: and criminals who, having forfeited their right to live in safety, were being fattened as food for wild beasts.
tgt_text.1220: There were great wooden stages, with towers formed of planks, like moveable houses, adorned outside with pictures, and serving as hand­ some receptacles for the performers in the exhibition.
tgt_text.1221: And then what a number, what a diversity of wild beasts!
tgt_text.1222: For he had been at great pains to procure, even from abroad, those noble living tombs of condemned men."
tgt_text.1223: Among his other costly preparations, he had procured, in.
tgt_text.1224: one way or other, with all the resources of his fortune, a great number of huge bears.
tgt_text.1225: For, besides those captured by his own servants in the chase, and those which he had bought at much cost, others had been presented to him by his friends, who vied with each other in showing him these attentions;
tgt_text.1226: and the whole collection was maintained with great care and cost.
tgt_text.1227: These noble and splendid preparations, however, for the public amusement, could not escape the evil eye of invidious Fortune.
tgt_text.1228: For these bears, pining and wasting away under their length­ ened confinement, the burning heat of the summer, and the debilitating effects of want of exercise, were attacked by a sudden mortality, and reduced to a very inconsiderable num­ ber.
tgt_text.1229: Hence, you might everywhere have seen bodies of half- dead bears lying in the streets, like so many shipwrecked vessels;
tgt_text.1230: and the ignoble mob, whose poverty compelled them to fill their pinched bellies with any filthy offal, began to flock about the food that was lying in all directions.
tgt_text.1231: "Prompted by this circumstance, Babulus here and I thought of the following clever stratagem.
tgt_text.1232: We carried the fattest of these bears to our lodging, as though intending to pre­ pare it for food;
tgt_text.1233: and having entirely stripped the skin from the flesh, carefully preserving all the claws, and leaving the head of the beast entire, as far as articulation with the neck, we care­ fully scraped the hide, sprinkled it with fine ashes, and exposed it in the sun to dry.
tgt_text.1234: While it was being purified of its oily juices by the heat of that celestial fire, we gorged ourselves with its pulpy flesh, and made those of the troop who were pre­ sent take an oath to this effect:
tgt_text.1235: that one of our number--one who surpassed the rest, not so much in stoutness of body as of heart, and above all, one who should undertake it voluntarily- being covered with this skin, should assume the form of a bear, and then, being brought into the house of Demochares, should, on a seasonable occasion, afford us an easy entrance through the door, in the dead of night."
tgt_text.1236: No few of our gallant troop did the cleverness of this scheme encourage to undertake its execution;
tgt_text.1237: but Thrasyleon was elected by the suffrages of the band as the fittest to per­ form the hazardous service.
tgt_text.1238: With a serene countenance, he enclosed himself in the hide, which was now rendered soft and pliable;
tgt_text.1239: then with fine stitches we drew the edges together, and covered the fine seams with the thick shaggy hair, fitting Thrasyleon's head into the part close by the back of the mouth, where the neck of the beast had been, and leaving small holes for breathing about the nostrils and the eyes.
tgt_text.1240: Lastly, we enclosed our most valorous comrade, now changed into a wild beast, within a cage which we had bought for a small sum, into which he sprang with unflinching courage;
tgt_text.1241: and having thus completed the preliminaries of the stratagem, we proceeded to the execution of the remainder."
tgt_text.1242: Having learned, on enquiry, the name of a person called Nicanor, who was sprung from a Thracian family, and between whom and Demochares there were the strongest ties of friend­ ship, we wrote a counterfeit letter, intimating that this kind friend had dedicated the first fruits of his hunting to Demo­ chares, by way of a graceful present.
tgt_text.1243: And now, the evening being far advanced, availing ourselves of the favourable dark­ ness, we presented to Demochares the cage in which Thrasy­ leon was enclosed, together with the counterfeit letter;
tgt_text.1244: on which, admiring the huge size of the beast, and overjoyed at the opportune liberality of his friend, he immediately gave orders that ten pieces of gold should be counted out from his coffers to us who had brought him a present that afforded him so much delight.
tgt_text.1245: Meanwhile, as novelty always excites the curiosity of men and attracts them to unexpected sights, mul­ titudes flocked together about the brute, admiring its size;
tgt_text.1246: but our friend Thrasyleon very cleverly restrained their rather too prying curiosity, by frequently rushing at them in a very alarming way.
tgt_text.1247: By the unanimous voice of the citizens, Demo­ chares was pronounced most lucky and fortunate, in that, after so heavy a loss among his wild beasts, he had been able, in some way or other, to repair his losses by this new supply.
tgt_text.1248: He or­ dered the beast, therefore, to be immediately taken to his farm, and that it should be conveyed with the greatest care.“
tgt_text.1249: On. this, I interrupted him, and said, ‘ Be careful, sir, how you suffer this animal, which has suffered severely from the heat of the sun, and the length of the distance, to be trusted among a herd of many others, and those, according to what I hear, not yet recovered.
tgt_text.1250: Why not provide some spot in your own house for it, which is open and exposed to the breezes, and, if possible, bordering upon some cool lake ?
tgt_text.1251: Are you not aware that animals of this kind always couch in shady groves and dripping caverns, on breezy hills, and near pleasant fountains ?'
tgt_text.1252: Demo­ chares, taking the alarm at these admonitions, and reflecting on the great number of wild beasts he had already lost, as­ sented, without hesitation, to what I said, and readily permitted us to place the cage wherever we pleased.
tgt_text.1253: ‘Besides,’ said I, ' we ourselves are ready to watch here by night, before this cage, in order that we may as carefully as is requisite give the beast its food at the proper time, and its usual drink, as it is distressed by the heat, and the harass it has suffered in being brought hither.'
tgt_text.1255: ‘We do not stand in need of your services;
tgt_text.1256: for nearly every one in my household is now, from long custom, well skilled in feeding bears.'"
tgt_text.1257: After this, we bade him farewell;
tgt_text.1258: and going out of the gate of the city, we espied a certain monument, standing at a con­ siderable distance from the public road, in a solitary and retired spot.
tgt_text.1259: Here we opened some coffins,* which, through rottenness and age, had lost half of their lids, and which were tenanted by dead bodies, that were now nothing but dust and ashes.
tgt_text.1260: These we intended to use as so many hiding-places for our an­ ticipated booty.
tgt_text.1261: Then having, according to the observance -of our craft, watched for that season of a moonless night in which sleep most powerfully invades and overcomes the hearts of mortals with its first impetus, our band drew up, -well-armed with swords, before the gates of Demochares, ready to perform our agreement to plunder his house.
tgt_text.1262: In like man­ ner, Thrasyleon crept forth from his cage, availing himself of that precise moment of the night which is adapted to theft, and instantly slew with his sword every one of the house guards that lay fast asleep beside his cage, and lastly, the porter him­ self.
tgt_text.1263: Then, taking the key, he opened the folding doors-of the gate, and as we immediately rushed in, he pointed out to us the strong room, where he had sagaciously observed a quantity of silver plate deposited in the evening.
tgt_text.1264: This being instantly broken open by the combined force of our band, I recommended each of my comrades to carry away as much gold and silver as he could, and conceal it in those abodes of the dead, the most trusty of all people, and then returning with speedy steps, get ready a second burden, whilst I would remain alone, for our common good, before the door of the house, and keep a careful watch, until such time as they should return.
tgt_text.1265: Moreover, it appeared to me that the figure of a bear, running about in the middle of the house, was adapted to terrify any member of the family who might happen to be awake.
tgt_text.1266: For who, however brave and intrepid he might naturally be, would not, on behold­ ing the huge form of such an enormous beast, in the night espe­ cially, immediately betake himself to flight, and pulling to the bolt, shut himself in, terrified and trembling, in his chamber ?“
tgt_text.1267: A sinister event, however, thwarted all these judicious ar­ rangements.
tgt_text.1268: For while I was waiting, in anxious suspense, for the return of my comrades, one of the servant lads, happen­ ing, so the Gods ordained, to be awoke by the noise, I suppose, of the bear, crept gently forward, and seeing the wild beast running loose, and wandering over the whole house, he silently retraced his steps, and, as quickly as he could, gave notice to all of what he had seen;
tgt_text.1269: immediately upon which, the whole house was filled with a numerous assemblage of the domestics.
tgt_text.1270: The darkness was illuminated with torches, lamps, wax tapers, tallow candles, and other appliances for giving light by night.
tgt_text.1271: And not one was there in the throng without arms of some de­ scription, but all were furnished with clubs, spears, and drawn swords, with which they guarded the approaches to the house.
tgt_text.1272: And then they hallooed on some of those hunting dogs, with long ears and shaggy hair, to attack the wild beast.“
tgt_text.1273: Upon this, the tumult still increasing, I made my way stealthily out of the house, and concealing myself behind the gate, I saw Thrasyleon defending himself in a wonderful manner against the dogs.
tgt_text.1274: For, though he had now arrived at the very uttermost goal of life, still, forgetful neither of himself nor of us, nor his former valour, he struggled, as it were, in the very jaws of Cerberus.
tgt_text.1275: In fact, acting with spirit up to the scenic character which he had voluntarily assumed, at one moment flying and at another resisting, with various gestures and con.

tgt_text.2130: At last one of them, having prevailed on the rest to cease the tumult, addressed them thus, in a mild and placid tone :
tgt_text.2132: It does not accord with the ordinances of our association, nor with the clemency of each of us, nor indeed with my own moderation, to suffer you to inflict punishment which exceeds the magnitude of the crime;
tgt_text.2133: nor that you should employ for this purpose wild beasts, or the cross, or fire, or torments, or invoke the hasty darkness of a rapid death.
tgt_text.2134: Hearken, then, to my counsel, and grant life to the maiden, but such life as she deserves.
tgt_text.2135: You have not, of course, forgotten what you some time ago decreed respecting that ass, who was always sluggish, indeed, but a prodigious eater, and who now also has counterfeited lameness, and has made himself the in­ strument and servant of the virgin's flight.
tgt_text.2136: It will be well, therefore, to cut his throat to-morrow, and, having taken out all his intestines, to sew up the virgin, naked, in the belly of the ass, who has preferred her to us;
tgt_text.2137: so that, her face alone may project and be visible, and the rest of her body may be confined in the beastly embrace of his belly.
tgt_text.2138: Then let the ass, with the virgin thus sewn up in him, be exposed, on some stony cliff, to the heat of the burning sun.
tgt_text.2139: Thus both of them will suffer everything which you have rightly decreed.
tgt_text.2140: For the ass will be put to death, as he has long ago deserved;
tgt_text.2141: while she will endure the bites of creatures of prey, when her limbs are gnawed by worms;
tgt_text.2142: the scorching heat of fire, when the blazing sun shall have burnt up the belly of the ass;
tgt_text.2143: and the torment of the cross, when dogs and vultures tear out her en­ trails.
tgt_text.2144: Reckon up, too, her other, miseries and torments.
tgt_text.2145: In the first place, she will remain alive in the belly of a dead beast;
tgt_text.2146: in the next place, her nostrils will be filled with a most fetid vapour;
tgt_text.2147: and, in the third place, she will waste away with protracted hunger, and will not have her hands at liberty to end her agonies by death.
tgt_text.2148: "After he had spoken to this effect, the robbers agreed to his proposal, which they relished to their very heart's content.
tgt_text.2149: On hearing their decision with my long cars, what could I do but bewail my poor body that was to be a dead carcase next morning ?
tgt_text.2150: As soon as darkness gave place to the fair light of day, and all things were illuminated by the splendid chariot of the sun, a certain person, one of the robbers' comrades, arrived;
tgt_text.2151: for so he appeared to be, by their mutual salutations.
tgt_text.2152: This man sat down at the entrance of the cavern, and after he had reco­ vered his breath, and was able to speak, he made the following narration to his companions :
tgt_text.2154: With respect to the house of Milo, of Hypata, which we lately plundered, we may now be quite at our ease, and fear nothing.
tgt_text.2155: For after you, brave men, had returned to our cave, carrying off with you all Milo's property, I mingled with the crowd of the citizens, and assuming the appearance of one who was grieved and indignant at what had happened, observed what course was taken for an investigation of the affair, and whether, and to what extent, they would inquire after the robbers;
tgt_text.2156: in order that I might relate to you every particular, conformably to your injunctions.
tgt_text.2157: Now one Lucius, whoever he may be, was accused, by the unanimous voice of all the mul­ titude, as the manifest author of the robbery, and this not upon dubious surmises, but upon convincing evidence.
tgt_text.2158: This Lucius, not long before, by false commendatory letters, passing himself off for a respectable man, strongly ingratiated himself with Milo, so that he was hospitably received by him, and ranked among his intimate friends.
tgt_text.2159: And when he had remained there not a few days, having ensnared the mind of a maid servant of Milo with false love, he diligently explored the bolts and bars of the house, and curiously surveyed those parts of it in which all the property was usually deposited.
tgt_text.2160: This, also, was con­ sidered as no small indication of his guilt, that he fled on the very same night, and at the very moment the robbery was committed, and has not been heard of since.
tgt_text.2161: He had ready means of flight too, whereby he could rapidly elude his pur­ suers, and get farther and farther away from their search;
tgt_text.2162: for he rode away on his own white horse.
tgt_text.2163: Moreover, his servant was found in the same house, and, being accused as accessary to the felony and escape of his master, was, by order of the magis­ trates, committed to the common gaol, and subjected on the fol­ lowing day to many torments.
tgt_text.2164: But though tortured till he was almost dead, he confessed, after all, nothing of the kind.
tgt_text.2165: Nevertheless, many persons were sent to the country of tha' Lucius in search of him, in order that he might undergo the punishment of his crime.
tgt_text.2166: "While he was narrating these things, my vitals were wrung with grief at the comparison they suggested between my an­ cient fortune and my present calamity, between that once happy Lucius and a miserable jackass.
tgt_text.2167: It also occurred to me, that not without reason had ancient sages pronounced Fortune to be blind, and entirely deprived of eyes;
tgt_text.2168: since she always bestows her riches on the unworthy and the wicked, and never judiciously makes any mortal the object of her regard;
tgt_text.2169: but indeed attaches herself for the most part to men from whom, if she could see, she ought to By far away.
tgt_text.2170: And what is worst of all, she causes opinions to be entertained of us that are at variance with our real character, or even contrary to it;
tgt_text.2171: so as to enable the bad man to exult in the renown of the good man, and, on the other hand, to cause the most innocent to suffer such punishment as befits the most guilty.
tgt_text.2172: Here, methought, am I, to whom she has done her worst in changing me into a beast, and a quadruped of the vilest condition, I, whose mis­ fortune would strike the most hardened reprobate as worthy to be lamented and commiserated, I am here accused of the crime of burglary, committed upon my most dear host;
tgt_text.2173: a crime for which burglary is too mild a name, and which one may more rightly denominate parricide.
tgt_text.2174: Yet I was not permitted to defend myself, or to utter so much as one word in denial of the charge.
tgt_text.2175: Now, however, when it was made in my presence, lest my silence should be mistaken for the acquiescence of a guilty conscience, I was racked with impatience to speak, were it only to say, Non feci, I did not do that deed.
tgt_text.2176: The former word, indeed, [non] I roared out again and again, but the other [feci]
tgt_text.2177: I could by no means pronounce, but I continued to vociferate non non ;
tgt_text.2178: and no more could I get out, though I made my pendulous lips vibrate with excessive rotundity.
tgt_text.2179: Why, however, do I prolixly complain of the spitefulness of Fortune, since she was not ashamed to make me a fellow- servant and yoke-mate with my own horse.
tgt_text.2180: While these thoughts were floating through my mind, a concern of a more important nature engaged my attention, viz., the recollection that I was destined by the decree of the robbers to be a victim to the manes of the virgin;
tgt_text.2181: and frequently casting a look at my belly, I seemed to myself to have the unhappy damsel enclosed within it.
tgt_text.2182: The robber who had just brought t he news of that false accusation against me, having drawn out a thousand pieces of gold coin, which he had sewn up and concealed in his garment, and which he had taken, as he said, from different travellers, and had conscientiously brought to the common treasury, began to inquire anxiously concerning the welfare of his comrades.
tgt_text.2183: Finding that some of them, and indeed all the bravest, had perished by various deaths, but all with great gallantry, he advised them to leave the highways at peace for some time, and rather apply themselves to searching after other associates, and to supplying the deficiency of their warlike band by the election of new hands from among the youths of the country.
tgt_text.2184: For, he observed, those that were unwilling might be com­ pelled by fear, and the willing be incited by reward;
tgt_text.2185: and not a few would gladly abandon an abject and servile life, and unite themselves to an association which possessed a power like that of royalty.
tgt_text.2186: For his own part, he had some time since met with a certain man of a lofty stature, young, of vast bodily dimensions, and of great strength;
tgt_text.2187: and after much ar­ gument had at length persuaded him to make better use of his hands, which had become torpid through long idleness;
tgt_text.2188: to enjoy while he might the advantages of a prosperous condition of body;
tgt_text.2189: and instead of holding out his powerful hand for alms, to exert it rather in helping himself to gold.
tgt_text.2190: All present assented to what he said, and decreed to receive the man he had spoken of, as he Appeared to be a tried man, and also to search after others who might supply the places of those they had lost.
tgt_text.2191: He went out, and returning shortly after, brought with him, as he had promised, a certain tall young man, with whom I do not think any one present could have stood a comparison;
tgt_text.2192: for, besides the great bulk of his body, he surpassed all the rest in height by a whole head, and yet the down had but just begun to overspread'his cheeks.
tgt_text.2193: He was only half clothed, with odds and ends of cloth, cobbled together, through the joinings of which his brawny breast and belly seemed ready to burst forth.
tgt_text.2194: Thus entering, " All hail," said he, " ye, who are under the protection of the most powerful God Mars, and who are now become my trusty comrades;
tgt_text.2195: receive willingly a willing recruit, a man of magnanimous spirit, who more cheerfully receives wounds in his body than gold in his hand, and who despises death, which others dread.
tgt_text.2196: And think not that I am a needy or abject man, nor judge of my merits from these rags;
tgt_text.2197: for I have been the leader of a most powerful band, and have, in fact, plundered all Macedonia.
tgt_text.2198: I am that famous robber Hæmus the Thracian, whose name whole provinces dread;
tgt_text.2199: and am the offspring of There, who was an equally illustrious robber;
tgt_text.2201: educated among bands of men of this description, and the heir and imitator of my father's valour.
tgt_text.2202: But I lost in a short space of time all my old band, all my brave comrades, and, all the great wealth we had amassed.
tgt_text.2203: For passing by Oratum,* I attacked one of Caesar's commissaries, who had been high in office, but was afterwards deprived of his employment through the malignity of fortune.
tgt_text.2204: I will, however, relate the whole affair in order that you may understand it the better."
tgt_text.2205: There was a certain person honourably distinguished by the many offices he held in the palace of Caesar, and who was also well esteemed by Cæsar himself.
tgt_text.2206: Malignant envy, and the crafty accusations of certain persons, hurled him into exile.
tgt_text.2207: But his wife, Plotina, a woman of rare fidelity and singular chastity, who had given stability to the family of her husband by the birth of ten children, spurned and despised the plea­ sures of city luxury, and became the companion of her husband's flight, and a partaker of his misfortune.
tgt_text.2208: For this purpose she cut off her hair, changed her dress, so that she might appear like a man;
tgt_text.2209: and begirt with necklaces of the greatest value and with zones of gold coin, she moved intre­ pidly amidst the drawn swords of the soldiers that guarded her husband, a partaker of all his dangers, maintaining an ever- wakeful care for his safety, and enduring continual labours with the fortitude of a man.
tgt_text.2210: And now having vanquished the greater part of the difficulties of the journey, and the dangers of the sea, she went with her husband to Zacynthus, † which their fatal destiny had decreed to be their temporary habita­ tion.
tgt_text.2211: As soon, however, as they had arrived on the shores of Actium, where we were then roving about on our return from Macedonia, they went late at night to a certain cottage which was near the shore and their ship, and there they slept in order to avoid the tossing of the sea.
tgt_text.2212: In this cottage we attacked and plundered them of every thing.
tgt_text.2213: Yet we did not depart without great danger.
tgt_text.2214: For as soon as the mistress of the house heard the first noise of the gate, she ran into the bedchamber, and disturbed all that were in the house by her tumultuous clamours.
tgt_text.2215: She likewise called on her servants by name, and on all her neighbours;
tgt_text.2216: but it so happened that we escaped with impunity through the general fear, each conceal­ ing himself out of regard to his own safety."
tgt_text.2217: This excellent woman, however, (for the truth must be spoken), who was a pattern of fidelity and was beloved for her virtues, immediately pouring forth her prayers to the majesty of Cæsar, obtained both a speedy return for her husband, and a complete revenge of the assault.
tgt_text.2218: In short, Cæsar was un­ willing that the band of the robber Hæmus should any longer exist, and it was forthwith immediately destroyed.
tgt_text.2219: So much can the mere wish of a great prince effect.
tgt_text.2220: At length, when, by the pertinacious pursuit of the emperor's army, all our band was destroyed, I scarcely saved myself, and escaped from the midst of the jaws of hell, after the following manner.
tgt_text.2221: I clothed myself in the florid vestment of a woman, with nume­ rous flowing folds, covered my head with a small woven mitre, and put on my feet those white and thin shoes which are worn by women;
tgt_text.2222: and thus, as it were, implanted and concealed in the other sex, I passed through the midst of the troops of hostile soldiers, riding on an ass laden with sheaves of barley.
tgt_text.2223: For, believing me to be a female ass-driver, they let me pass free;
tgt_text.2224: because at that time my beardless cheeks were still soft and smooth as a boy's.
tgt_text.2225: Yet I have not degenerated from my paternal glory, or forgotten my fortitude, though somewhat fearful in consequence of being placed in the midst of martial blades ;
tgt_text.2226: but protected by the disguise of a dress foreign to my sex, and attacking villas or towns, single handed, I have pro- sured for myself this small viaticum by plunder."
tgt_text.2228: Ripping open his rags as he spoke, he poured forth into the midst of them two thousand pieces of gold coin.
tgt_text.2229: "There," said he, "I willingly offer to your band this contribution, and myself also (if you do not reject my offer), as a most faithful leader, who, in a short space of time, will make this your habitation to be no longer rocky, but golden."
tgt_text.2230: The rob­ bers, without hesitation, unanimously elected him their leader.
tgt_text.2231: They also brought forth a tolerably fair garment, which he put on, throwing away his rich rags.
tgt_text.2232: And having thus changed his attire, and embraced each of them, he was placed on the couch at the head of the table, and his leadership was inaugu­ rated by a supper, and copious bowls.
tgt_text.2233: In the conversation that ensued, the robber was made aware of the flight of the damsel, of my carrying her, and of the monstrous death to which each of us was destined.
tgt_text.2234: He asked where the virgin was, and being taken to her, and seeing her laden with chains, he turned away from her, with a contemp­ tuous curl of his nose, and said :
tgt_text.2235: "I am not indeed so stupid, or at least so rash, as to oppose your decree;
tgt_text.2236: but I should have to endure the reproaches of my own conscience, if I dissembled what appears to me to be for your benefit.
tgt_text.2237: But, in the first place, suffer me, who am solicitous for your sake, to speak boldly, especially since, if my views are not acceptable to you, you may fall back on what you have decreed concerning the virgin and the ass.
tgt_text.2238: Now, I think that those robbers who are truly wise ought to prefer nothing to their own gain, not even vengeance itself, which is often detrimental to those who inflict it as well as to others.
tgt_text.2239: If, then, you destroy the virgin in the body of the ass, you will gratify nothing but your indig­ nation, without any profit to yourselves.
tgt_text.2240: It is my opinion that she should rather be taken to some city, and there sold;
tgt_text.2241: for a virgin of her age may be sold for no small price.
tgt_text.2242: I myself, some time ago, knew certain bawds, one of whom might, as I think, give a great sum of money for this virgin, and place her in a brothel, suitable to her birth, and from which she will not be likely to run away again.
tgt_text.2243: She will also have afforded you some revenge, when she has passed into bondage at a brothel.
tgt_text.2244: I have sincerely offered this counsel to you, as conducive to your advantage ;
tgt_text.2245: but you are the masters of your own judg­ ments and acts."
tgt_text.2246: Thus it was that this advocate of the rob­ bers' exchequer, and no less excellent saviour of the virgin and ass, pleaded our cause.
tgt_text.2247: The rest of the robbers, after tormenting my entrails and my miserable spirit by their tedious deliberations, at length cor­ dially acceded to the opinion of the new robber, and immedi­ ately freed the virgin from her bonds.
tgt_text.2248: But as for her, from the moment she beheld that young man, and heard him men­ tion a brothel and a bawd, she began to be elated, and to smile most joyfully, so that I felt inclined, with good reason, to vitu­ perate the whole sex, when I saw a virgin, who pretended that she was enamoured of a young lover, and was desirous of a chaste marriage, now suddenly delighted with the name of a vile and filthy brothel.
tgt_text.2249: It was a case in which the character of the whole female sex was in question, and the verdict de­ pended on the judgment of an ass.
tgt_text.2250: The young man, how­ ever, resuming his discourse, said :
tgt_text.2252: Why do we not proceed to supplicate Mars to be propitious to us in selling the virgin, and searching for other associates ?
tgt_text.2253: But, as far as I see, we have not any beast for sacrifice, nor sufficient wine for drink­ ing largely.
tgt_text.2254: Send with me, therefore, ten of our comrades, with whom I may go to the next town, and bring you thence meat and drink fit for priests."
tgt_text.2255: Accordingly, he departed, attended by ten of the robbers, and the rest prepared a great fire, and raised an altar of green turf to the god Mars.
tgt_text.2256: The foragers soon returned, bringing with them skins full of wine, and driving before them a great number of cattle;
tgt_text.2257: from among which they selected a large he-goat, old and shaggy, and sacrificed it to Mars the Secutor* and Associate.
tgt_text.2258: A sumptuous supper was immediately prepared.
tgt_text.2260: "You must consider me as a strenuous leader not only of your plundering expeditions, but also of your pleasures."
tgt_text.2261: And with that he went cleverly to work, and performed every thing that was requisite with admirable dexterity.
tgt_text.2262: He swept the floor, made the couches smooth, cooked the meat, seasoned the dishes, and served them up handsomely;
tgt_text.2263: but especially he plied each of them, and that frequently, with large bowls of wine.
tgt_text.2264: Nevertheless, under pretence of fetching what he wanted from time to time, he often went to the virgin, and gaily presented her with fragments which he had se­ cretly taken away, and cups of wine, of which he had pre­ viously tasted.
tgt_text.2265: And she most willingly received what he brought her, and sometimes, when he wished to kiss her, she readily responded to his wish, and kissed him.
tgt_text.2269: Shame upon you, girl, do you forget your faithful lover and your nuptials ?
tgt_text.2270: Do you prefer this foreign and cruel homicide to that young man, whoever he be, to whom your parents have betrothed you ?
tgt_text.2271: Does not your conscience prick you, that you thus trample on affection, and are pleased to act libidinously among gleaming spears and swords ?
tgt_text.2272: What if the other rob­ bers, likewise, should, by some means or other, perceive what you are doing, would you not again return to the ass, and again procure my destruction?
tgt_text.2273: Really you are playing your game at the risk of another's skin.
tgt_text.2274: Whilst I was thus cogitating in great indignation, and falsely accusing the virgin in my own mind, I gathered from certain words of theirs, which though dubious, were not obscure to an intelligent ass, that the young man was not the famous robber Hsemus, but Tlepolemus, the bridegroom of the virgin.
tgt_text.2275: For, in the course of their conference, caring nothing for my pre­ sence, he said somewhat more distinctly:
tgt_text.2276: " Be of good cheer, dearost Charite;
tgt_text.2277: for you shall presently have all these your enemies in captivity."
tgt_text.2278: And I observed that while he himself refrained from drinking immoderately, he never ceased to ply the robbers more and more with wine, now unmingled with water, and moderately heated, so that they began to be over­ come with intoxication.
tgt_text.2279: And, by Hercules, I suspect that he had mingled in their cups a certain soporiferous drug.
tgt_text.2280: At last, when they all, without a single exception, lay dead drunk on the floor, then Tlepolemus, having without any difficulty bound them strongly with ropes, and tied them together as he thought proper, placed the damsel on my back, and directed his steps to his own home.
tgt_text.2281: As soon as we arrived there, the whole city turned out at the wished-for sight.
tgt_text.2282: Parents, kindred, retainers, bondmen, and servants, joyfully ran out to meet us.
tgt_text.2283: You might see a procession of every age and sex, and, by Hercules, a new and memorable spectacle, a virgin riding in triumph on an ass.*
tgt_text.2284: As for myself, rejoicing with all my might, and not choosing to be at variance with the present display, as if I had no concern in it, I brayed strenuously, with erect ears and expanded nos­ trils, or rather, I trumpeted with a noise like thunder.
tgt_text.2285: The damsel having now retired to her chamber, where her parents cherished and caressed her, Tlepolemus immediately took me back to the cave, accompanied by a great number of beasts of burden, and a multitude of his fellow-citizens.
tgt_text.2287: for, curious at all times, I was then particularly desirous to be a spectator of the captivity of the robbers, whom we found still fast bound, with wine even more than with ropes.
tgt_text.2288: Having, therefore, ransacked the cave, and brought out every thing that was in it, and we, and all the rest being loaded with gold and silver, Tlepolemus and his at­ tendants rolled some of the robbers, bound as they were, over the neighbouring cliffs, and others they beheaded with their own swords.
tgt_text.2289: Then we returned to the city, exulting and re­ joicing in so complete a revenge.
tgt_text.2290: The robbers' wealth was deposited in the public treasury;
tgt_text.2291: but the damsel, who had been recovered by Tlepolemus, was given to him according to law.
tgt_text.2292: Then that noble woman paid the greatest attention to me, whom she called her saviour;
tgt_text.2293: and, on the very day of her nuptials, ordered my manger to be completely filled with bar­ ley, and as much hay to be given me as would be enough for a Bactrian eamel.
tgt_text.2294: But what sufficiently dire execrations could I imprecate on Fotis, who had transformed me not into a dog, but an ass, when I saw all the dogs stuffed and crammed with the relics of the most abundant supper, and with the food they had pillaged ?
tgt_text.2295: After the first night, the bride did not cease to tell her parents and her husband how greatly she was in­ debted to me, till they promised that they would confer on me the- highest honours.
tgt_text.2296: Convoking, therefore, their most inti­ mate friends, they held a consultation as to how I might most worthily be rewarded.
tgt_text.2297: One was of opinion that I should be shut up in the house, and there, leading an idle life, be fattened with choice barley, beans, and vetches.
tgt_text.2298: But the opinion of another prevailed, who regarded my liberty, and persuaded them rather to give me the run of the plains and meadows, where I might take ray pleasure among the herds of horses, and procreate many mules, for the masters of the mares.
tgt_text.2299: The keeper of the horses was accordingly summoned, and I was delivered over to him, with many injunctions that he should take care of me.
tgt_text.2300: And right gaily did I trot along by his side, rejoicing at the thought that I was now to have nothing more to do with packs and bags, and so forth, and that having obtained my liberty, I should doubtless find some roses in the meadows, when they began to blossom in spring.
tgt_text.2301: Frequently, too, it occurred to me, that since such great marks of gratitude and so many honours were conferred on me when but an ass, so much the greater would be the re­ spect and favour shown me when I had recovered the human form.
tgt_text.2302: But when the keeper of the horses had taken me to the country, I found there none of the pleasure or the liberty I ex­ pected.
tgt_text.2303: For his wife, an avaricious, bad woman, immediately yoked me to the mill, and frequently striking me with a green stick, prepared bread for herself and her family at the expense of my hide.
tgt_text.2304: And not content to make me drudge for her own food only, she also ground corn for her neighbours, and so made money by my toil.
tgt_text.2305: Nor, after all my weary labours, did she even afford me the food which had been ordered for me;
tgt_text.2306: for she sold my barley to the neighouring husbandmen, after it had been bruised and ground in that very mill, by ray own round­ about drudgery;
tgt_text.2307: but to me, who had worked during the whole of the day at that laborious machine, she only gave, towards evening, some dirty, unsifted, and very gritty bran.
tgt_text.2308: I was brought low enough by these miseries ;
tgt_text.2309: but cruel Fortune ex­ posed me to fresh torments, in order, I suppose, that I might boast of my brave deeds, both in peace and war, as the saying is.
tgt_text.2310: For that excellent equerry, complying, rather late, indeed, with his master's orders, for a short time permitted me to as­ sociate with the herds of horses.
tgt_text.2311: At length a free ass, I capered for joy, and softly ambling up to the mares, chose out such as I thought would be the fittest for my concubines.
tgt_text.2312: But here my joyful hopes gave place to extreme danger.
tgt_text.2313: For the stallions, who had been fed high for the sake of copulating with the mares, and who, independently of this, were terribly strong creatures, more than a match for any ass, regarding me with suspicion, and anxious to preserve the purity of their race, furiously pursued me as their rival, without respect for the laws of hospitable Jupiter.
tgt_text.2314: One of them, with his head and neck and ample chest aloft, struck at me like a pugilist with his forefeet;
tgt_text.2315: another, turning his brawny back, let fly at me with his hind feet;
tgt_text.2316: and another, with a vicious neigh, his ears thrown back, and showing his white teeth, sharp as spears, bit me all over.
tgt_text.2317: It was like what I have read in history of the King of Thrace,* who exposed his unhappy guests to be lacerated and devoured by wild horses.
tgt_text.2318: For so sparing was that power­ ful tyrant of his barley, that he appeased the hunger of his voracious horses by casting human bodies to them for food.
tgt_text.2319: In fact, I was so worried and distracted by the continual attacks of the horses, that I wished myself bark again at the mill round.
tgt_text.2320: Fortune, however, who could not be satiated with my tor­ ments, 'soon after visited me with another calamity.
tgt_text.2321: For I was employed to bring home wood from a mountain, and a boy, the most villanous of all boys, was appointed to drive me.
tgt_text.2322: It was not only that I was wearied by toiling up and down the steep and lofty mountain, nor that I wore away my hoofs by running on sharp stones, but I was cudgelled without end, so that all my bones ached to the very marrow.
tgt_text.2323: More­ over, by continually striking me on the off-haunch, and always in the same place, till the skin was broken, he occa­ sioned a great ulcerous cavity, gaping like a trench or a window;
tgt_text.2324: yet he never ceased to hit me on the raw.
tgt_text.2325: He likewise laid such a load of wood on my back, that you might have thought it was a burden prepared for an elephant, and not for a jackass.
tgt_text.2326: And whenever the ill-balanced load inclined to one side, instead of taking away some of the faggots from the heavier side, and thus easing me by somewhat lightening, or at least equalizing the pressure, he always remedied the inequality of the weight by the addition of stones.
tgt_text.2327: Nor yet, after so many miseries which I had endured, was he content with the immoderate weight of my burden;
tgt_text.2328: but when it happened that we had to pass over a river, he would leap on my back in order to keep his feet dry, as if his weight was but a trifling addition to the heavy mass.
tgt_text.2329: And if by any acci­ dent I happened to fall, through the weight of my burden, and the slipperiness of the muddy bank, instead of giving me a helping hand as he ought to have done, and pulling me up by the headstall, or by my tail, or removing a part of my load, till at least I had got up again;
tgt_text.2330: this paragon of ass-drivers gave me no help at all, however weary I might be, but begin­ ning from my head, or rather from my ears, he thrashed all the hair off my hide with a huge stick, till the blows stirred me up and served me instead of a stimulating medicament.
tgt_text.2331: Another piece of cruelty he practised on me, was this.
tgt_text.2332: He twisted together a bundle of the sharpest and most venomous thorns, and tied them to my tail as a pendulous torment;
tgt_text.2333: so that, jerking against me when I walked, they pricked and stabbed me intolerably.
tgt_text.2334: Hence, I was in a sore dilemma.
tgt_text.2335: For when I ran away from him, to escape his unmerciful drubbings, I was hurt by the more vehement pricking of the thorns;
tgt_text.2336: and if I stood still for a short time, in order to avoid that pain, I was compelled by blows to go on.
tgt_text.2337: In fact, the rascally boy seemed to think of nothing else than how he might be the death of me by some means or other;
tgt_text.2338: and that he sometimes threatened with oaths to accomplish.
tgt_text.2339: And, indeed, there happened a thing by which his detestable malice was stimulated to more baneful efforts ;
tgt_text.2340: for on a certain day, when his excessive insolence had overcome my patience, I lifted up my powerful heels against him ;
tgt_text.2341: and for this he retaliated by the following atrocity.
tgt_text.2342: He brought me into the road heavily laden with a bundle of coarse flax, securely bound together with cords, and placed in the middle of the burden a burning coal, which he had stolen from the neighbouring village.
tgt_text.2343: Presently the fire spread through the slender fibres, flames burst forth, and I was all over in a blaze.
tgt_text.2344: There appeared no refuge from immediate destruction, no hope of safety, and such a conflagration did not admit of delay, or afford time for deliberation.
tgt_text.2345: Fortune, however, shone upon me in these cruel circumstances ;
tgt_text.2346: perhaps for the purpose of reserving me for future dangers, but, at all events, liberating me from present and decreed death.
tgt_text.2347: For by chance perceiving a neighbouring pool muddy with the rain of the preceding day, I threw myself headlong into it;
tgt_text.2348: and the flame being immediately extinguished, I came out, lightened of my burden, and liberated from destruction.
tgt_text.2349: But that audacious young rascal threw the blame of this most wicked deed of his on me, and affirmed to all the shepherds, that as I was passing near the neighbours' fires, I stumbled on purpose, and set my load in a blaze ;
tgt_text.2350: and he added, laughing at me, "How long shall we waste food on this fiery monster?
tgt_text.2351: "A few days after this, he had recourse to still worse artifices against me.
tgt_text.2352: After having sold my load of wood at the nearest cabin, he led me home unladen, declaring that he could not mar age so vicious a brute, and that he renounced the miserable office of being my driver.
tgt_text.2354: Look at that lazy, crawling, out-and-out jackass," said he. "
tgt_text.2355: Besides all his other miss- deeds, he is now worrying me with new ones that put me in mortal fear.
tgt_text.2356: For whenever he sees a traveller, be it a comely woman, or a marriageable girl, or a tender youth, he imme­ diately makes at them as if he was mad, upsetting his burden, and sometimes pitching off his very pack-saddle, and throws them down with abominable intentions, makes up his great ugly mouth as if to kiss them, and bites and tramples them most indecently.
tgt_text.2357: All this occasions us no small strife and quarrels, and will perhaps bring us into trouble with the ma­ gistrates.
tgt_text.2358: Just now, espying a decent young woman, this frolicksome gallant ran at her, scattering all his wood, threw her down in the mud, and wanted to have his wicked will of her there and then.
tgt_text.2359: Had not her shrieks brought some people to her help, who were passing that way, and who snatched her half dead from under his hoofs, she must have died a horrible death, and left us to suffer the last penalty of the law.
tgt_text.2360: "With these and other such lies, which hurt my modesty the more because I could not reply to them, he desperately incensed the herdsmen against me.
tgt_text.2361: At last said one of them, " Why do we not immolate as he deserves this public paramour, this universal adulterer ?
tgt_text.2363: cut off his head, throw his entrails to the dogs, and keep his flesh to feed the work­ people ;
tgt_text.2364: then we will carry his skin, well rubbed with ashes and dried, to our master, and easily make up a story of his having been killed by a wolf.
tgt_text.2365: Without delay my villanous accuser prepared joyfully to execute the herdsman's sentence with his own hand, and began to sharpen his knife on a whetstone, mocking, my woe, and maliciously calling to mind the kick I had given him, and which, by Hercules !
tgt_text.2367: But one of the rustics exclaimed that it was a shame to slaughter so fine an ass. "
tgt_text.2368: Why lose the services of so useful a beast," he said, " merely because he is too lustful ?
tgt_text.2369: Only geld him, and he can no how play his pranks any more ;
tgt_text.2370: we shall be safe from danger on his account, and besides, he will grow stouter and fatter than ever.
tgt_text.2371: I have known many an animal, not asses merely, but even high-spirited horses, that were so hot after mares, as to be quite furious and unmanageable, and which, after being cut, became quiet and fit to carry loads or do any- thing else that was required of them.
tgt_text.2372: So if you have no ob­ jection to what I say, after I have been to the market, which will not detain me long, I will fetch the implements from home, and immediately come back and geld this terrible rude gallant, and make him gentler than any wether.
tgt_text.2373: "Snatched by this proposal from the very clutches of death, but reserved for a most cruel punishment, I grieved as though I were about to perish wholly in losing an appendage to my body, and thought of destroying myself by continual fasting, or by leaping down a precipice:
tgt_text.2374: in that way I should die none the less, but I should die entire.
tgt_text.2375: Whilst I was pondering my choice of deaths, morning came again, and that boy, who was my tormentor, led me as usual up the mountain, where fastening me to a branch of great oak, he went a little way off, and began to cut down a load of wood with his axe.
tgt_text.2376: Just then, I saw a horrid bear lift up its great head, and creep out of a cave close by.
tgt_text.2377: Appalled at the sudden sight, I started back, sinking down with all my might upon my haunches, while my head and neck were held up by the thong, until it broke ;
tgt_text.2378: whereupon I dashed down the mountains, not on my feet only, but projecting myself bodily, reached the plains beneath, and scoured across them, running with all my might from the dreadful bear, and the boy that was worse than the bear.
tgt_text.2379: A man who was passing that way, seeing me roam at large, caught me, got on my back, and thumping me with a stick, turned me into a side road unknown to me.
tgt_text.2380: I carried him along with good will, thinking I was running away from that cruel operation, and caring little about the blows I received, for I was used to that sort of thing.
tgt_text.2381: But Fortune, with her inveterate malice, anticipated so opportune a chance of escape, and gave me over to fresh sufferings.
tgt_text.2382: For my master's herds­ men having gone out in all directions to look for a stray heifer, Happened to fall in with us, and seizing me by the head stall, which they readily identified, they began to lead me away.
tgt_text.2383: My rider, however, making a bold resistance, called gods and men to witness against them. "
tgt_text.2384: Why do you pull me about in this violent way ?" he said, "
tgt_text.2385: Why do you lay hands on me ?
tgt_text.2387: "Do we behave unjustly to you," said- the herdsmen, " when we find you making off with our ass ?
tgt_text.2388: Tell us where you have hid the body of his driver, whom you have killed, no doubt."
tgt_text.2389: So saying, they knocked him to the ground, and kicked and pummelled him with their fists, he swearing all the while that he had seen no one with the ass, but had found it running away, alone, and had caught it, that he might restore it to its owner, and be rewarded for his trouble."
tgt_text.2390: Would to heaven!" he cried, " that I had never seen this ass, or that he could speak with a human voice, and bear testi­ mony to my innocence.
tgt_text.2391: You would surely be ashamed of the way in which you treat me.
tgt_text.2392: "But all his protestations were of no avail, for the angry herdsmen marched him along, with a rope round his neck, to the forest on the mountain, where the boy used to fetch wood.
