tgt_text.3828: Then, in my right hand I carried a burning torch;
tgt_text.3829: while a graceful chaplet encircled my head, the shining leaves of the palm tree projecting from it like rays of light.
tgt_text.3830: Thus arrayed like the sun, and placed so as to resemble a statue, on a sudden, the curtains being drawn aside, I was ex­ posed to the gaze of the multitude.
tgt_text.3831: After this, I celebrated the most joyful day of my initiation, as my natal day, and there was a joyous banquet and mirthful conversation.
tgt_text.3832: The third day also was celebrated with the like rites and cere­ monies, and was accompanied by a religious breakfast, and the due termination of the ceremonial.
tgt_text.3833: After this, having stayed for some days in that place, I enjoyed the inexplicable pleasure of viewing the holy image, being indebted to it for a benefit which can never be sufficiently rewarded.
tgt_text.3834: At length, how­ ever, through the admonition of the Goddess, having suppli­ antly given her thanks, not such as she deserved, but still, to the best of my ability, I prepared myself, though very slowly, to return home.
tgt_text.3835: With difficulty did I rend asunder the ties of my most ardent affection.
tgt_text.3836: At last I prostrated myself in the presence of the Goddess, and having for a long time watered her feet with my tears, interrupting my words by frequent sobs, and, as it were, half swallowing my voice, I thus addressed her:
tgt_text.3837: —“ Thou, 0 holy and perpetual preserver of the human race, always munificent in cherishing mortals, dost bestow the sweet affec­ tion of a mother on the misfortunes of the wretched.
tgt_text.3838: Nor is there any day or night, nor so much as the minutest particle of time, which passes unattended by thy bounties.
tgt_text.3839: Thou dost protect men both by sea and land, and, dispersing the storms of life, dost extend thy health-giving right hand, by which thou dost unravel the inextricably entangled threads of the Fates, and dost assuage the tempests of fortune, and restrain the malignant influences of the stars.
tgt_text.3840: The gods of heaven adore thee, those in the shades below do homage unto thee;
tgt_text.3841: thou dost roll the sphere of the universe round the steady poles, thou dost illuminate the sun, thou dost govern the universe, thou dost tread the realms of Tartarus.
tgt_text.3842: The stars move re­ sponsive to thy command, the Gods rejoice in thy divinity, the seasons return by thy appointment, and the elements are thy servants.
tgt_text.3843: At thy nod the breezes blow, the clouds are nur­ tured, the seeds germinate, and the blossoms increase.
tgt_text.3844: The birds as they hover through the air, the wild beasts as they roam on the mountains, the serpents that hide in the earth, and the monsters that swim in the sea, are terrified at the ma­ jesty of thy presence.
tgt_text.3845: But I, so weak in capacity for cele­ brating thy praises, and possessing such slender means for offering sacrifices, have far from eloquence sufficient to express all that I conceive of thy majesty;
tgt_text.3846: not a thousand mouths, and tongues as many, not an eternal flow of unwearied speech, would be equal to the task.
tgt_text.3847: I will, therefore, use my utmost endeavours to do what, poor as I am, still one truly religious may do—I will figure to myself thy divine countenance, and will ever preserve this most holy divinity locked up in the deepest recesses of my breast.
tgt_text.3848: "After this manner, having offered up my prayer to the supreme Goddess, I embraced the priest Mithras, who was now my parent, and hanging on his neck, and giving him many kisses, I begged him to forgive me, that I could not remunerate him in a manner adequate to such mighty benefits.
tgt_text.3849: At length, after having been long engaged in giving him thanks, I de­ parted, and prepared to journey directly to my paternal abode, in order to revisit it after an absence so prolonged.
tgt_text.3850: A few days after, having hastily tied up my packages, through the admonition of the powerful Goddess, embarking on board a ship, I set sail for Rome.
tgt_text.3851: Being sure of a favourable wind during my voyage, I very speedily entered into port, and tra­ velling by chariot* with the greatest rapidity, arrived at the holy city, † on the day before the Ides of December in the evening.
tgt_text.3852: Thenceforward no study was there of such primary importance with me, as that of daily supplicating the supreme divinity of Queen Isis;
tgt_text.3853: who is there propitiated with the greatest veneration under the name of Campensis,‡ which ap­ pellation she derives from the situation of her temple.
tgt_text.3854: In fine, I became a constant worshipper, a foreigner indeed as to her temple, but indigenous as to her religion.
tgt_text.3855: §Behold the mighty sun, having passed through the sign- bearing circle of the zodiac, had completed the year, when the vigilant care of the beneficent Goddess again interrupted my sleep, and again reminded me of initiation and sacred rites.
tgt_text.3856: On this I wondered what object she had in view, and what future event she announced.

tgt_text.3859: While, therefore, I revolved my religious doubts in my own mind, and availed myself of the counsels of the priest, I as­ certained a thing that was novel and quite wonderful to me;
tgt_text.3860: that I was only inititated into the mysteries of the goddess, but that I had not yet been admitted to the knowledge of the rites of the great God, and supreme parent of the Gods, the invincible Osiris.

tgt_text.3865: He also walked gently with a hesitating step, the ancle of his left foot being slightly bent, in order no doubt that he might afford me some sign, by which I might recognize him.

tgt_text.3868: Accordingly, the instant I had performed the morning salu­ tations to the goddess, I made a most careful examination of each, to see whether there was any one of the priests resem­ bling him whom I had seen in the dream.
tgt_text.3870: For I immediately beheld one of the Pastophori, exactly cor­ responding with the nocturnal vision, not only' with regard to the mark of his foot.
tgt_text.3871: but also in his stature and general ap­ pearance ;
tgt_text.3872: whose name I afterwards learnt to be Asinius Mar­ cellus, an appellation not without some degree of reference* to my transformation.
tgt_text.3873: Without delay, therefore, I addressed this priest, who was himself very far from ignorant of what I intended to say, because he had already been admonished by a similar mandate, that he should initiate me into the mysteries of Osiris.
tgt_text.3874: For on the preceding night, while he was placing chaplets on the statue of the great God, he imagined that he had also heard from that mouth of his by which he pronounces the destinies of all things, that he should send to him a native of Madaura, to whom, though he was very poor, he must im­ mediately impart the sacred mysteries.
tgt_text.3875: That, through his pro­ vidence, glory would accrue to that person from his religious exercises, and great profit for himself.
tgt_text.3876: After this manner, being affianced to the sacred mysteries, I was retarded, contrary to my inclination, by reason of the slenderness of my means.
tgt_text.3877: For the expense to which I had been put in my journey had frittered away the small substance of my property;
tgt_text.3878: and the sums I was obliged to expend in the city, exceeded those which had been disbursed in the provinces.
tgt_text.3879: Rigid poverty, consequently, greatly interfering with my wishes, I was much afflicted, being placed, as the old proverb says, between the altar and the stone. *
tgt_text.3880: Nor yet was I less urged from time to time by the present mandates of the God.
tgt_text.3881: At last, after being repeatedly reminded, and finally com­ manded, not without considerable perturbation, taking off my back my garment, small as it was, I scraped together a suf­ ficient sum.

tgt_text.4078: Have you not read Catullus, where he thus replies to the malevolent ? “
tgt_text.4079: 'Tis fit the worthy poet should be chaste-
tgt_text.4080: There's no need that his verses should be so.
tgt_text.4081: "The divine Adrian, when he honoured the tomb of his friend the poet Voconius with his verse, wrote to this effect:
tgt_text.4082: — " Wanton thou wast in verse, but chaste in mind a thing he never would have said, if verses somewhat sprightly were to be considered as indicative of pruriency of thought.
tgt_text.4083: I recollect, too, having read many verses of a similar character by the divine Adrian himself.
tgt_text.4084: Assert then, if you dare, Æmi­ lianus, that it is evil to do that which the divine Adrian, our emperor and censor, has done, and has handed down to memory as having been done by him.
tgt_text.4085: Besides, do you suppose that Maximus is likely to censure anything that he knows I have done after the example of Plato ?
tgt_text.4086: whose lines, which I just now quoted, are the more chaste for being undisguised, the more modest for their plainness of expression.
tgt_text.4087: For, to dissemble and to conceal these and all such matters, is the part of an offender, while, to discourse of them openly and without dis­ guise, is the part of him who speaks but in jest;
tgt_text.4088: for so it is, that by nature the power of utterance has been given to in­ nocence, while silence has been allotted to criminality.
tgt_text.4089: But I will forbear to enlarge upon those deep and holy mysteries of the Platonic philosophy, which, while they are revealed to but few of the pious, are totally unknown to all the profane ;
tgt_text.4090: how, that Venus is a twofold goddess, each of the pair producing a peculiar passion, and in different kinds of lovers
tgt_text.4091: One of them is the “ Vulgar," who is prompted by the ordinary passion of love, to stimulate not only the human feelings, but even those of cattle and wild beasts, to lust, and commit the enslaved bodies of beings thus smitten by- her to immoderate and furious embraces.
tgt_text.4092: The other is the "Heavenly" Venus, who presides over the purest love, who cares for men alone and but few of them, and who influences her devotees by no stimulants or allurements to base desire.
tgt_text.4093: For the love that is engendered by her is not a wanton or lascivious love, but, on the contrary, it is serious and unadorned, and allures its votaries to virtue by its own intrinsic beauty;
tgt_text.4094: and if at any time she does commend a graceful form, she scrupulously protects it against all cause for reproach.
tgt_text.4095: Nor, indeed, is there any­ thing else in the beauty of the person deserving of love, beyond the fact that it recalls to the mind which took its origin in Deity, that beauty which in all its truth and purity it once beheld among the gods.
tgt_text.4096: Hence it is, that Afranius, with his usual eloquence, has left this line :
tgt_text.4098: Where wise men love, all others will desire.
tgt_text.4099: "However, Æmilianus, if you wish to hear the truth, or if you can ever arrive at a perception of the fact, the wise man does not so much love, as recall to mind.*
tgt_text.4100: Do pardon, then, the philosopher Plato, for his verses on love, that I may not feel myself necessitated, contrary to the maxim of Neoptolemus in Ennius,* to "philosophize in detail;
tgt_text.4101: " or, at all events, if you decline to do so, I will readily submit, with reference to verses of this nature, to be censured in company with Plato.
tgt_text.4102: And to you, Maximus, I return abundant thanks, for having so attentively listened to these appendages to my defence, which I have deemed necessary, inasmuch as they are put forward in answer to charges brought against me;
tgt_text.4103: and for the same reason I request that you, will listen as readily and as attentively as you have hitherto done, to what I have to say, before I come to the main charges.
tgt_text.4104: For next follows the lengthy and cutting attack about the looking-glass, upon which, Pudens, screaming aloud, commen­ surately with the atrocity of the offence, almost burst him­ self, crying, " a philosopher has a looking-glass !-a philoso­ pher possesses a looking-glass !"
tgt_text.4105: Let me then confess that I have one, lest you should flatter yourself that you had hit me hard if I denied it;
tgt_text.4106: but it is by no means a necessary infer­ ence, that I am in the habit of dressing too before a looking- glass.
tgt_text.4107: For suppose I were in possession of a theatrical ward­ robe, would you argue thence that I was in the habit of using the long train of the tragedian, the saffron-coloured dress of the comedian, or the little mantle of the mimic, as at the triennial orgies of Bacchus ?
tgt_text.4109: And on the other hand, there is many a thing of which I am.
tgt_text.4110: not pos­ sessed, but of which I still enjoy the use.
tgt_text.4111: If, then, the possession of a thing is no proof of the use of it, or the non-possession of the non-use of it, and if not so much the possession of a looking-glass is censured by you, as the looking into it, it then necessarily follows, that you must shew when and in whose presence I looked into the glass;
tgt_text.4112: for, according to the present state of the case, you make it a greater offence for a philosopher to look into a looking- glass, than for one of the uninitiated to pry into† the mysteries of Ceres.
tgt_text.4113: Come now, even if I should confess that I have looked into it, pray what crime is it to be acquainted with one's own features, and to have their image not put up* in one fixed spot, but to carry it about in a little mirror, ready to be sur­ veyed wherever you please ?
tgt_text.4114: Are you ignorant that there is nothing more deserving to be viewed by a man than his own features ?
tgt_text.4115: For my part, I know that those sons are the mos beloved who bear the strongest resemblance to the parents and that a man's own statue is erected at the public expense in his honour as the reward of merit, in order that he may look upon the same ;
tgt_text.4116: else what is the use of statues and images thus framed with the varied resources of art ?
tgt_text.4117: unless, perchance, we admit that the very same thing that is worthy of admi­ ration.
tgt_text.4118: when produced by artistic skill, is to be deemed cul­ pable when presented by nature;
tgt_text.4119: whereas, on the contrary, the readiness and exactness of nature are even still more de­ serving of our admiration.
tgt_text.4120: For in tracing all likenesses by the hand, a considerable time is consumed in the work, and yet, after all, no resemblance is to be seen comparable with that to be viewed in a mirror;
tgt_text.4121: for clay is deficient in vigour, stone in colour, painting in firmness, while all are devoid of the power of motion, which brings the likeness before us in' the highest degree.
tgt_text.4123: the mirror is to be seen the image wonderfully re­ flected, not only with the resemblance traced out, but en­ dowed, too, with motion, and obedient to every gesture of the person whom it represents.
tgt_text.4124: Then, besides, it is always of the same age with the beholder, from the earliest boyhood down to the very close of old age:
tgt_text.4125: so many aspects of life does it assume, of such varied conditions of the body does it partake, such numerous changes of the same features, whether influenced by joy or by grief, does it imitate.
tgt_text.4126: But, on the other hand, the resemblance that is moulded from clay, formed of molten brass, hewn out of stone, impressed by heat on wax, laid on a surface with paint, or represented by any other re­ source of human art, after no long interval of time becomes quite unlike the original;
tgt_text.4127: and besides, it always preserves the same rigid unmoved features, just like a corpse.
tgt_text.4128: To such a degree then, does the highly-wrought smoothness of its po- lished surface, and artificial brightness of the mirror, surpass all art in reflecting the likeness of the person.
tgt_text.4129: Either, then, we are bound to adhere to the opinion of Agesilaus the Lacedæmonian, who having but a poor opinion of his own appearance, would never allow himself to be re­ presented in painting or sculpture, or else, if the usages of all the rest of mankind appear worthy to be retained, and statues and images are not to be eschewed, what reason have you to be of opinion that each man ought to see his likeness rather in stone than in silver, rather in a picture than in a mirror ?
tgt_text.4130: Do you think it a disgrace for a man carefully to survey his own figure ?
tgt_text.4131: Is it not said of the philosopher Socrates, that he even advised his disciples to view themselves repeatedly in a mirror, so that he among them who was smitten with his own good looks, might be the more scrupulously careful not to disgrace the beauty of his person by bad manners;
tgt_text.4132: while, on the other hand, he who thought himself not so highly gifted in appearance, might carefully use his best endeavours to screen his ugliness by his virtues.
tgt_text.4133: And thus did a man, who was wiser than all others, make use of the mirror for the purpose even of improving moral cultivation.
tgt_text.4134: Then too, who knows not how Demosthenes, that most ex­ cellent master in the art of oratory, always got up his causes before a mirror, just as though in presence of a master ?
tgt_text.4135: So that most excellent orator, after he had learned eloquence from the philosopher Plato, and the art of reasoning from Eubulides the logician, endeavoured to obtain the extreme perfection of the art of oratory by the assistance of the mirror.
tgt_text.4136: Which, then, do you think ought to pay the greater atten­ tion to grace in the impressive delivery of his language, the wrangling rhetorician or the warning philosopher ?
tgt_text.4137: the one who for a few moments disputes before certain judges who are chosen by lot, or the one who is continually discussing ques­ tions in the presence of all mankind;
tgt_text.4138: he who wrangles about the limits of fields, or he who defines the limits of good and evil ?
tgt_text.4139: Why, if it was only for this purpose, ought not a phi­ losopher to look into a mirror ?
tgt_text.4140: For it is often incumbent upon him not only to view his own likeness, but to consider too the manner in which that likeness is so reflected;
tgt_text.4141: whether it is that, as Epicurus says, images which emanate from our bodies in a perpetual flow, being a kind of slough, as it were, as soon as they strike against any smooth and solid surface, are thrown back again, and so turned the contrary way;
tgt_text.4142: or whether it is that, as other philosophers argue, our rays of vision, (whether flowing from the middle of the eyes, and mingling and uniting with the external light as Plato thinks, or whether only proceeding from the eyes without any foreign admixture whatever, as Archytas supposes, or whether being broken by the tension of the atmosphere, as the Stoics ima­ gine), when they have struck upon any body that is dense, smooth, and shining, rebound and return to the features at the same angles of incidence at which they have struck that body, and so represent in the mirror that which they touch and behold externally to it.
tgt_text.4143: Does it not seem to you to be a matter of duty that philosophers should investigate all these subjects and duly enquire into them, and that they ought to be the only persons to look into mirrors of all kinds, whether with a watery surface or with a dry ?
tgt_text.4144: For their province it is, besides what I have already mentioned, to enter upon that other enquiry, why in mirrors with a plain surface images generally appear alike, while in mirrors which are spherical and convex in surface, all objects appear diminished, and, on the other hand, in those which are concave they are magnified;
tgt_text.4145: at what distance and for what reason before a concave mirror the left hand takes the place of the right;
tgt_text.4146: in what cases it is that the image at one moment withdraws within, and at ano­ ther, seems to be stepping out* of the same mirror;
tgt_text.4147: why it is that a concave mirror, if it is held facing the sun ignites fuel placed close to it:
tgt_text.4148: how it happens that distinct rainbows are seen in the clouds, and that two suns exactly similar are to be beheld :
tgt_text.4149: besides numerous other questions of a similar na­ ture, which are discussed in the ample volume of Archimedes the Syracusan, a man endowed far beyond all other men with a wonderful degree of skill in all geometrical subjects;
tgt_text.4150: though I am not quite sure but he is worthy of especial note for the fact that he consulted the mirror often and carefully.
tgt_text.4151: If you had only been acquainted with his book, Æmilianus, and had applied yourself not only to your fields and your clods, but to the geometrician's board and fine sand, believe me, when I say it, that although your extremely ugly features differ but very little from those of the Thyestes of tragedy, there is no doubt but you would have looked into the mirror with the object of learning something new, and would at last have given up the plough, in the intensity of your admiration of the numerous furrows and wrinkles to be seen in your own face.
tgt_text.4152: Now, I should not wonder if you took it in very good part that I make mention of those most distorted features of yours, but am silent as to your manners, which are far more repulsive.
tgt_text.4153: The fact is, that whereas I am not naturally of a quarrelsome disposition, I was, moreover, quite willing until the last few days, to remain in ignorance whether you were a white or a black man, and even now, by Hercules!
tgt_text.4154: I am far from certain on that point.
tgt_text.4155: This arises from the fact, that while you have been buried in the obscurity of a country life, I have been busied with my studies.
tgt_text.4156: So, while the shade thrown around you by your ignoble condition has stood be­ tween yourself and an observer, I have never made it my object to learn the misdeeds of any person, but have always, in preference, studied how to veil my own failings rather than pry into those of others.
tgt_text.4157: I am just in the same position, then, with reference to you, as the man who chances to be standing in a place upon which a bright ligh is thrown, while another, concealed in deep shade, is looking at him.
tgt_text.4158: For just in a similar manner, while you can easily observe, in your obscurity, what I am doing in the open daylight and before all the world, you yourself, being concealed by your ignoble station, and shunning the light, cannot in your turn be dis­ tinguished by me.
tgt_text.4159: Hence it is, that whether you have slaves to till your lands, or whether you make exchange of labour with your neighbours, turn and turn about, I neither know nor am I anxious to know ;
tgt_text.4160: but you know very well that in one day I manumitted three slaves at Œa, * and this your advocate, among other points upon which he had been instructed by you, made an objection against me;
tgt_text.4161: although but very shortly before, he had asserted that I had come to Œa with but a single ser­ vant as my attendant.
tgt_text.4162: Now I wish you would answer me this:
tgt_text.4163: out of one servant how could I manumit three, unless this, too, is to be set down to the account of magic ?
tgt_text.4164: Am I to suppose that such is your blindness in lying, or such the inveteracy of that habit in you ? "
tgt_text.4165: Apuleius came to (Ea with a single servant," and then, after babbling out a few words, " Apuleius manumitted three slaves at (Ea in one day."
tgt_text.4166: Why, not even would your story have been credible, had you said that I had come attended by three servants, and had liberated them all;
tgt_text.4167: and yet if I had done so, why should you look upon the possession of but three servants as a mark of poverty, rather than the manumission of three as a proof of opulence ?
tgt_text.4168: You know not, most decidedly you know not, Æmilianus, how to bring a charge against a philosopher, when you throw in my teeth the scantiness of my retinue, a thing that I ought rather, for the sake of my own credit, to have feigned, had it been necessary so to do, inasmuch as I was well aware that not only the philosophers, of whom I profess to be a disciple, but even emperors of the Roman people have gloried in the small number of their servants.
tgt_text.4169: And have not your advocates, pray, read to the same effect ?
tgt_text.4170: How that M. Antonius, a man of consular dignity, had but eight servants in his house, and how that Carbo, who attained the highest honours, had one less ?
tgt_text.4171: And then, again, how Manius Curius, who was rendered so illustrious by his nume­ rous victories, for three times did he enter at the same gate in triumph, how that Manius Caius, I say, employed but two camp servants in his expeditions ?
tgt_text.4172: So likewise the man who triumphed over the Sabines, the Samnites, and Pyrrhus, had fewer servants in.
tgt_text.4173: number than the triumphs he enjoyed.
tgt_text.4174: Then, again, Marcus Cato, little expecting that others would mention it of him, has left it written in a speech of his, that when he set out as consul for Spain, he took with him from the city but three attendants, and no more;
tgt_text.4175: when he arrived, how­ ever, at the public villa,* these seemed too few for his re­ quirements, whereupon he ordered two youths to be purchased in the forum at the slaves' platform,† and these five he took with him to Spain.
tgt_text.4176: If Pudens had read all this, according to my way of thinking he would either have entirely spared this invective, or else in three servants he would have seen cause rather to censure the multitude of a philosopher's attend­ ants, than the scantiness of his retinue.
tgt_text.4177: He has even gone so far as to reproach me with my poverty, a charge truly acceptable to a philosopher, and one to which I readily plead guilty.
tgt_text.4178: For Poverty has long been the hand­ maid of Philosophy, frugal, temperate, contented with little, eager for praise, averse from the things sought by wealth, safe in her ways, simple in her requirements, in her counsels a promoter of what is right.
tgt_text.4179: No one has she ever puffed up with pride, no one has she corrupted by the enjoyment of power, no one has she maddened with tyrannical ambition;
tgt_text.4180: for no pampering of the appetite or of the passions does she sigh, nor can she indulge it.
tgt_text.4181: But it is your fosterlings of wealth who are in the habit of perpetrating these disgraceful excesses and others of a kindred nature.
tgt_text.4182: If you review all the greatest enormities that have been committed in the memory of mankind, you will not find a single poor man among the perpetrators:
tgt_text.4183: whilst, on the other hand, in the number of illustrious men, hardly any of the rich are to be found;
tgt_text.4184: poverty has nurtured from his very cradle every individual in whom we find anything to admire and commend.
tgt_text.4185: Poverty, I say, she who in former ages was the foundress of all cities, the inventress of all arts, she who is guiltless of all offence, who is lavish of all glory, who has been honoured with every praise among all nations.
tgt_text.4186: For this same Poverty it was that among the Greeks showed herself just in Aristides, humane in Phocion, resolute in Epaminondas, wise in Socrates, and eloquent in Homer.
tgt_text.4187: It was this same Poverty, too, that for the Roman people laid the very earliest founda­ tions of their sway, and that offers sacrifice to the immortal Gods in their behalf with the ladle and the dish of clay, even to this day.
tgt_text.4188: If there were now sitting as judges at this trial, C. Fabri- cius, Cneius Scipio, and Manius Curius, whose daughters, by reason of their poverty, went home to their husbands portioned at the public expense, carrying with them the glories of their family and the money of the public, if Publicola, the ex- peller of the kings, and [Menenius] Agrippa, the reconciler of the people, the expense of whose funerals was, in consequence of their limited fortunes, defrayed by the Roman people, by contributions of the smallest coins;
tgt_text.4189: * if Attilius Regulus, whose little field was, in consequence of a like poverty, cultivated at the public expense;
tgt_text.4190: if, in fine, all those ancient families, en­ nobled by consulships, censorships, and triumphs, could obtain a short respite, and return to light and take part in this trial, would you then have dared to reproach a philosopher for his poverty, in the presence of so many consuls distinguished for theirs ?
tgt_text.4191: Or is it that Claudius Maximus appears to you to be a suit­ able listener, while you are deriding poverty, because he hap­ pens to be the owner of an ample estate ?
tgt_text.4192: You are mistaken, AEmilianus, and little are you acquainted with his feelings, if you form your estimate of him according to the indulgence of Fortune, and not according to the strict rules of philosophy;
tgt_text.4193: if you suppose that a man of such rigid morals and so long used to warfare, is not better disposed towards circumscribed mode­ ration than fastidious opulence ;
tgt_text.4194: if you suppose that he does not approve of wealth on the same principles that he does a garment, rather when it suits the person than when it is re­ markable for its length.
tgt_text.4195: For wealth, too, if it is not conve­ niently carried, becomes an impediment to us, and trips us up, no less than a draggling garment.
tgt_text.4196: Indeed, in all matters which are needed for the requirements of life, every thing that steps beyond becoming moderation is superfluous, and is rather a burden to us than useful.
tgt_text.4197: Hence it is, that immo­ derate wealth, just like a large and disproportioned rudder, is more apt to sink than to guide, for in such a case people have a useless abundance, a pernicious superfluity.
tgt_text.4198: I see, besides, that among the most opulent persons, those are especially commended who make no bustle., no immo­ derate show;
tgt_text.4199: who live without thrusting their wealth into' public view, who manage their vast resources without ostenta­ tion and without pride, and who imitate the poor in the appear­ ance of limited means.
tgt_text.4201: even seek a certain appearance-a colour of poverty-in order to put on the sem­ blance of limited means, why should those who are poorer be ashamed of it, when they have to endure a poverty not affected, but real ?
tgt_text.4202: I could, indeed, raise an argument with you about the very name itself, and I could show that none of us are poor who do not wish for superfluities, and who possess the things that are necessary, which, by nature, are but few indeed.
tgt_text.4205: he who wants but little, is most likely to have as much as he wants.
tgt_text.4206: For this reason it is that riches are not better estimated according to lands and income than according to a man's own mind;
tgt_text.4207: for if a man is craving through avarice, and always greedy of gain, not even by mountains of gold will he be satisfied, but he will be always begging for something, that he may increase his store.
tgt_text.4208: And this is the real exposition of poverty.
tgt_text.4209: For all desire of acquiring, arises from the opinion which each man entertains as to what is poverty.
tgt_text.4210: And it matters not how great is the amount of which you are in want—Philus had not so great an estate as Lælius, Lælius as Scipio, Scipio as Crassus the Rich, nor even Crassus the Rich as he wished.
tgt_text.4211: So that, although he surpassed all in wealth, he himself was surpassed by his own avarice, and seemed to be rich in the eyes of all others rather than in his own.
tgt_text.4212: But, on the other hand, those philoso­ phers of whom I have made mention, wishing for no more than they could obtain, and actuated by desires commensurate with their means, were rightfully and deservedly rich and opulent.
tgt_text.4213: For you become poor through the want of acquisition, and rich through having no wants to satisfy;
tgt_text.4214: inasmuch as a state of po­ verty is ascertained from the manifestation of desire, opulence from the fact of being satisfied.
tgt_text.4215: Therefore, Æmilianus, if you wish me to be accounted poor, you must of necessity first show that I am avaricious.
tgt_text.4216: For if, in my mind, there is nothing want­ ing, I care not what external things may be wanting;
tgt_text.4217: for in the abundance of these consists no praise, in the want of them no blame.
tgt_text.4218: Suppose, however, that it is otherwise, and that I really am poor, because Fortune has denied me riches;
tgt_text.4219: suppose that, as often is the case, either my guardian has made away with them, an enemy robbed me of them, or my father failed to leave me any ;
tgt_text.4220: is a man, then, to be censured for a thing which is imputed as a fault to no one of the animals, neither the eagle, nor the bull, nor the lion ?
tgt_text.4221: If a horse has good qualities, and is an easy trotter, and swift in his gallop, no one censures him for being in want of fodder;
tgt_text.4222: and will you impute it as a fault to me, not that I have said or done anything that is bad, but that I live contented with my .humble means, that I have but few servants, that I eat sparingly, that I am lightly clad, and that I cater but meagrely ?
tgt_text.4223: And yet, on the other hand, small as you think my means in all these respects, I both think them abundant, and more than sufficient, and I desire to restrict myself to still fewer necessities, being fully assured that I shall be the more happy, the more circumscribed my wants.
tgt_text.4224: For it is wivh the mind just as with the body;
tgt_text.4225: in a healthy state it is lightly clad, but in sickness it is wrapped in cumbrous clothing and it is a sure sign of infirmity to have many wants.
tgt_text.4226: It is with life just as with swimming;
tgt_text.4227: that man is the most ex­ pert who is the most disengaged from all encumbrances.
tgt_text.4228: Just the same way, amid the stormy tempests of human life, that which is light tends to our buoyancy, that which is heavy, to sink us.
tgt_text.4229: For my part, I have learned that in this especially the Gods surpass mankind, that they have to satisfy no necessities.
tgt_text.4230: Hence it is, that him among us who has the fewest possible necessities, I consider most strongly to resemble a God.
tgt_text.4231: I was very well pleased, therefore, when you said, intending it as a reproach, that my property consisted of a staff and a wallet.
tgt_text.4232: And I only wish that I had such perfect control over my mind, that I required nothing whatever beyond those articles, and be­ comingly submitted to the same equipment which Crates, throwing all riches aside, spontaneously desired.
tgt_text.4233: This Crates, if you will take my word for it, JEmilianus, was a man of the higher class of Thebes, rich, and ennobled in his city through his love of that very state which you impute to me as a fault.
tgt_text.4234: He presented his large and ample property to the people, and putting away his numerous retinue of servants, made choice of a life of solitude;
tgt_text.4235: his trees, numerous and fruitful as they were, he scorned in comparison with a single staff;
tgt_text.4236: his most elegant villas he changed for a single scrip;
tgt_text.4237: the praises of which he afterwards even sang in verse, on experience of its utility, adapting to the purpose those lines of Homer in which he celebrates the Isle of Crete.
tgt_text.4238: I will mention the words with which he commences, that you may not suppose I have only invented this for the purpose of my defence— " Scrip is a city's name,* which 'mid dense smoke Lies fair and flourishing."
tgt_text.4239: And then follow lines so admirable, that, if you were to read them, you would be much more inclined to envy me my wallet than the hand of Pudentilla.
tgt_text.4240: Do you censure philosophers for their scrip and staff ?
tgt_text.4241: By the same reasoning, you ought to censure horsemen for their trappings, foot-soldiers for their bucklers, standard-bearers for their ensigns, and those, in fine, who enjoy a triumph for their white steeds, and their robes embroidered with sprigs of palm.
tgt_text.4242: These, however, are not the equipments of the Platonic sect, but they are the insignia of the class of Cynics.
tgt_text.4243: Still, the scrip and the staff were the same to Diogenes and to An- tisthenes, as the diadem to kings, the martial cloak to generals, the rounded hat to priests, and the crooked staff to augurs.
tgt_text.4244: Indeed, Diogenes the Cynic, when disputing with Alexander the Great as to who was the true king, boasted of his staff as serving him in the stead of a sceptre.
tgt_text.4245: Even the invincible Hercules himself—(you will, no doubt, feel a perfect contempt for those others, as a set of mendicants) —
tgt_text.4247: self, I say, the traveller over the whole earth, the cleanser thereof from wild beasts, the subduer of nations, when he was travelling through the earth, and shortly before he was sum­ moned to heaven for his virtues, had no better clothing than a single hide, although he was a God,' and no other attendants than a single staff.
tgt_text.4248: If, however, you think nothing at all of these instances, and have summoned me not to plead a cause, but to discourse upon my income, that you may not be in ignorance about any of my affairs, if, indeed, you are ignorant, I admit that my father left me and my brother a little under twenty hundred thou­ sand sesterces, and that that sum has been a little diminished by me, in consequence of prolonged travel, close study, and fre­ quent donations.
tgt_text.4249: For I have given assistance to most of my friends, paid their fees to numbers of instructors, and have given dowries even to the daughters of some :
tgt_text.4250: nor indeed, for my own part, should I have hesitated to spend even the whole of my patrimony, in order to acquire, what to me is of far .
tgt_text.4251: greater value, a. contempt for all wealth.
tgt_text.4252: You, on the other hand, JEmilianus, and men like you, un­ polished and uncouth, are to be valued, no doubt, just according to what you possess ;
tgt_text.4253: just as a barren and unproductive tree, which bears no fruit, is to be estimated in value according to the amount of timber to be found in its trunk.
tgt_text.4254: Nevertheless, forbear, Æmilianus, from this time forward, to throw his poverty in the teeth of any man, seeing that, up to a very re­ cent date, you used to plough for three days single-handed the one little field at Zaratha, which your father left you, with the assistance of a solitary ass to get it ready before the usual wet season.
tgt_text.4255: Nor is it such a very long time since the nume­ rous deaths of relatives came to your support, by giving you the possession of property that you little deserved ;
tgt_text.4256: a circum­ stance from which, still more than from that most ugly face of yours, you have obtained the name of Charon.
tgt_text.4257: And now as to my native country, and your shewing that it is situate on the confines of Numidia and of Getulia, from writings of mine, in which I confessed, when I was lecturing before that most illustrious man, Lollianus Avitus, that I was a Semi-Numidian and a Semi-Getulian;
tgt_text.4258: I do not see what I have to be ashamed of in that respect, any more than the elder Cyrus, because he was of mingled parentage, being a Semi-Median and a Semi-Persian.
tgt_text.4259: For the proper subject of enquiry is not where.
tgt_text.4260: a man is born, but what are his man­ ners ;
tgt_text.4261: not in what country, but upon what principle he began life is the thing to be considered.
tgt_text.4262: It is with good reason allowed the gardener and the vintner to recommend vege­ tables and wine according to the nobleness of the soil;
tgt_text.4263: the wine of Thasos,* for instance, and the vegetables of Phlius.
tgt_text.4264: For it is a fact, that those productions of the earth are much im­ proved in flavour by the natural fertility of the district, the rain of the heavens, the mildness of the breezes, the brightness of the sun, and the richness of the soil.
tgt_text.4265: But, on the other hand, while the mind of man is sojourning in the abode of the body which is foreign to it, how can any of these particulars in any way add to or subtract from its merits or its demerits ?
tgt_text.4266: When was it not the case that in every nation various dispositions were to be found ?
tgt_text.4267: and this, al­ though some of them seem to be peculiarly distinguished for stupidity, others for talent.
tgt_text.4268: Among the Scythians, a people most remarkable for their stupidity, was born the wise Ana­ charsis;
tgt_text.4269: among the clever Athenians, the fool Melitides.
tgt_text.4270: Nor do -I say this because I am in any way ashamed of my country, even though ours had still been the city of Syphax ;
tgt_text.4271: * we, however, were conquered, on which we were presented as a gift of the Roman people to king Masinissa, and after that, on a new allotment of land being made among the veteran sol­ diers, we rose to be what we now are, a most famous colony.
tgt_text.4272: In this colony it was, that my father, a man of the highest rank, a duumvir, enjoyed every honour;
tgt_text.4273: whose position I have occupied in the same community, from the time I was admitted to the rank of decurion, having in no way dege­ nerated from him, and, I both hope and think, enjoying the same amount of honor and of estimation.
tgt_text.4274: Why do I mention these particulars ?
tgt_text.4275: In order that you, Æmilianus, may have the fewer pretences for levelling your invectives against me in future;
tgt_text.4276: and that you may be the more inclined to pardon me, if, in my negligence, I did omit to make choice of that Attic Zarath † of yours, to be born in.
tgt_text.4277: Are you not ashamed of yourselves, thus perseveringly, in the presence of such a man, to prefer such accusations as these ?
tgt_text.4278: To bring forward matters so frivolous, and at the same time of so conflicting a nature, and yet to charge me as being guilty of them all ?
tgt_text.4279: Have you not accused me on con­ tradictory grounds ?
tgt_text.4280: on those of the wallet and the staff, be­ cause of my rigidness of life;
tgt_text.4281: on those of the verses and the looking-glass, on account of my frivolity;
tgt_text.4282: of having but one servant, as being penurious;
tgt_text.4283: of having three freedmen, as being a spendthrift;
tgt_text.4284: and then, besides, of being in eloquence a Greek, by birth a barbarian.
tgt_text.4285: Why do you not rouse up your senses, and recollect that you are pleading your cause before Claudius Maximus, before a man of serious habits, and one engaged with the affairs of this entire province ?
tgt_text.4286: Why not away with these vain reproaches ?
tgt_text.4287: Why not prove, whit you have accused me of, heinous crimes, lawless misdeeds, and wicked artifices ?
tgt_text.4288: Why is your speech thus weak in argu ments, thus mighty in outcry ?
tgt_text.4289: I now come to the charge itself of magic, that blazing brand which you lighted up against me with such immense clamour, but which has disappointed the expectation of all, dying out into I know not what old woman's stories.
tgt_text.4290: Have you not, Maximus, sometimes beheld a fire that has broken out amid stubble?
tgt_text.4291: how loud its crackling, how large its blaze, how rapid its growth, and yet, after all, how slight the fuel on which it feeds, how short-lived the flame, that leaves after it no remains!
tgt_text.4292: In that flame behold this accusation, which began in abuse, which has been fanned by assertions, which has failed in its proofs, and which, after your sentence shall have been pronounced, is destined to survive in not a single remnant of this false charge:
tgt_text.4293: a charge which has been en­ tirely centred by Æmilianus in the proof of this one point, that I am a magician;
tgt_text.4294: for which reason I may be allowed to enquire of these most learned advocates of his, what a magician is.
tgt_text.4295: For if, as I have read in many authors, a magician* means, in the language of the Persians, the same thing that the word “ priest" does in ours, what is the crime, pray, in being a ma­ gician ?
tgt_text.4296: what is the crime in properly knowing, and under­ standing, and being versed in the laws of ceremonials, the solemn order of sacred rites, and religious ordinances ?
tgt_text.4297: What if, indeed, that is magic, which Plato calls " the service of the Gods," when he relates with what careful training the Per­ sians bring up a youth who is destined for the throne.
tgt_text.4298: I recollect the very words of that divine man, and do you, Maximus, recall them to your memory with me:
tgt_text.4299: " When he is fourteen years of age, those persons take charge of the boy, whom they call 'the royal tutors.'
tgt_text.4300: These are four persons, whom they select from the highest classes of the Persians, and who are ap proved of for their age.
tgt_text.4301: One of these is the most wise, ano­ ther the most just, another the most prudent, and the fourth the most valiant man.
tgt_text.4302: Of these, one instructs him in the magic of Zoroaster and of Oromazes, which is the service of the Gods.
tgt_text.4303: He also teaches him the art of governing.
tgt_text.4304: "Do yoa not hear then, you who are so rash as to accuse me of it, that magic is an art acceptable to the Gods, one that most correctly teaches us how to worship and to venerate them;
tgt_text.4305: one that is consequently consistent with piety, and skilled in all divine matters;
tgt_text.4306: one that has been ennobled from the very times of Zoroaster and of Oromazes, its inventors, as being the handmaid of the inhabitants of heaven ?
tgt_text.4307: For among the very rudiments of the royal training this art is taught;
tgt_text.4308: nor is any one of the Persians rashly allowed to be a magician, any more than he is to be a king.
tgt_text.4309: The same Plato, in another discourse of his, when speaking of a certain Zamolxis, a Thracian by birth, but a man skilled in the same art, has left a passage in his writings to the fol­ lowing effect:
tgt_text.4310: —“ But he said, 0 happy man, that the soul is healed by certain incantations;
tgt_text.4311: and that these incantations are soothing words."
tgt_text.4312: And if this is the fact, what reason is there why I should not be allowed to understand either the soothing words of Zamolxis, or the priestly duties enjoined by Zoroaster ?
tgt_text.4313: But if, after the common usage, these people ima­ gine that a magician is properly a person who, from commu­ nication and discourse with the immortal Gods, is able, by a certain incredible power centred in his incantations, to do everything he pleases, then I greatly wonder, why they have not been afraid to accuse me, when they admit that I am possessed of such mighty powers.
tgt_text.4314: For you cannot take pre­ cautions against a power that is of a nature so mysterious and so divine, in the same way that other influences may be guarded against.
tgt_text.4315: He who summons an assassin before the judge, comes there attended by others;
tgt_text.4316: he who accuses a poi­ soner, uses every precaution in taking his food;
tgt_text.4317: he who charges a man with theft, keeps watch over his property.
tgt_text.4318: But here, on the other hand, he who puts a magician, such as they speak of, on trial for his life, by means of what attend­ ants, what precautions, what guards, is he to ward off a de­ struction that is as unforeseen as it is inevitable ?
tgt_text.4320: hence a charge of this kind is not likely to be preferred by one who believes in its truth.
tgt_text.4321: But these accu­ sations, by a kind of error universally prevalent among the ignorant, are generally made against philosophers;
tgt_text.4322: thus, for instance, such of them as make enquiry into the pure and pri­ mary causes of matter, they look upon as irreligious, and, on that account, assert that they deny the existence of Gods;
tgt_text.4323: such as Anaxagoras, Leucippua, Democritus, Epicurus, and other advocates of natural causes;
tgt_text.4324: others, again, who, with more than ordinary curiosity, enquire into the governance of the world, and with the greatest earnestness venerate the Gods, to these, too, do the vulgar give the name of magicians;
tgt_text.4325: sup­ posing that they know how to bring about those operations which they know to take place:
tgt_text.4326: such, for instance, were in former days, Epimenides, Orpheus, Pythagoras, and Ostanes.*
tgt_text.4327: In like manner, the Purifications of Empedocles, the Daemon of Socrates, and the abstract " Good" of Plato, became similar objects of suspicion.
tgt_text.4328: Consequently, I congratulate myself, when I find myself added to this long list of great men.
tgt_text.4329: Still, I am afraid that the frivolous, silly, and trifling things that they have alleged against me in support of their charge, you will consider to make against me, if only on the ground that they have been so alleged.
tgt_text.4330: “ Why," said he, “ have you been enquiring after certain kinds of fishes ?"
tgt_text.4331: Just as though a philosopher were not at liberty to do that, in the cause of knowledge, which an epicure may do to satisfy his gluttony.
tgt_text.4332: "Why has a free-born woman married you after she has passed fourteen years in a state of widowhood ?"
tgt_text.4333: Just as though it were not a greater cause for wonderment that she remained unmarried so many years. "
tgt_text.4334: Why, before she was married to you, did she write I know not what thoughts of hers in a certain letter ?"
tgt_text.4335: Just as though any one were bound to tell another the reasons for his thoughts. "
tgt_text.4336: Then, besides, she, a person advanced in years, did not hesitate to marry a young man."
tgt_text.4337: Why, that very fact, affords a proof that there was no need of magic to prompt a woman to marry a man, a widow a bachelor, one advanced in years, her junior;
tgt_text.4338: and then come these other points of a similar nature—“ Apuleius has got something at home which he worships in secret."
tgt_text.4339: Just as though it would not rather be a ground for crimination not to have some object to worship. " A boy fell down in the pre­ sence of Apuleius."
tgt_text.4340: And what if a young, man, what if an old man even had fallen to the ground while I was standing by, whether he happened to be attacked by some bodily malady, or lost his balance through the slippery natuie of the ground ?
tgt_text.4341: Is it on these proofs you would convict me of magical prac­ tices—the tumbling down of a boy, the marriage of a woman, and the purchase of some fish ?
tgt_text.4342: For my own part, I certainly could, with entire safety to myself, be content, after saying even thus much, to come to a conclusion.
tgt_text.4343: Still as, in proportion to the lengthiness of the speech made for the prosecution, the water [in the clepsydra] shows that there is abundance of time left, let us, if you think proper, consider things in detail.
tgt_text.4344: And, for my part, all the charges that have been brought against me, whether they are true or false, I shall not deny, but will admit them, just as though they really were the fact;
tgt_text.4345: so that all this vast multi­ tude, which has flocked together from every quarter to hear this trial, may fully understand, that not only nothing can be truthfully alleged against philosophers, but that nothing even can be falsely devised against them, which they would not prefer to rebut, although they could deny it, in full reliance on their innocence.
tgt_text.4346: First, then, I will meet their arguments, and will prove that they bear no relation whatever to the practice of magic;
tgt_text.4348: I will show that, even if I had been a magician of first-rate ability, still, no cause or opportunity has existed for them to detect me in any mal­ practice whatever.
tgt_text.4349: I will at the same time discuss more fully their unfounded envy, their shameful conduct in reading the letters of this lady, and their still more disgraceful interpreta­ tion put upon those letters, with.
tgt_text.4350: all the circumstances of the marriage between.
tgt_text.4352: and I will show that I entered into that alliance more from a sense of duty than for gain.
tgt_text.4353: And, really, what a mighty cause of torment and uneasi­ ness has this marriage of ours.
tgt_text.4355: Hence all that anger, and rage, and absolute frenzy,, which have found a vent in the present prosecution.
tgt_text.4356: And if I shall succeed in proving all these points clearly and distinctly, then I shall call upon you, Claudius Maximus, and all you who are here present, to bear witnessthat this youth, Sicinius Pudens, my son-in-law, in whose name and by whose wish I am accused by his uncle, has but just-now been removed from my charge, since his bro­ ther Pontianus, his senior in years, and his superior in character, departed this life;
tgt_text.4357: and I will show that he has been thus nefa­ riously worked upon against myself and his mother, through no fault of mine;
tgt_text.4358: and that, having forsaken the pursuits of literature, and abandoned all studies, he is likely, if we may form a judgment from the wicked plans betrayed in this accu­ sation, to turn out much more like his uncle Æmilianus than his brother Pontianus.
tgt_text.4359: I will now proceed, as I originally purposed, to all the frantic conceptions of Æmilianus here, and I will begin with that one which you heard him state at the outset as affording the strongest grounds for suspecting me of the practice of magic- the fact, I mean, that I have purchased various kinds of fish of some fishermen.
tgt_text.4360: Which, now, of these circumstances is it that is to lead to a suspicion of magic ?
tgt_text.4361: Is it the fact that fishermen have endeavoured to procure these fish for me ?
tgt_text.4362: I suppose, then, this task ought to have been entrusted to some dyers or carpenters;
tgt_text.4363: and that, on the same principle, the pur­ suit of every art ought to have changed hands, so that the carpenter should have netted fish for me, and the fisherman have planed wood.
tgt_text.4364: Or, is it that you feel satisfied that fishes must be sought for unlawful practices, because they are sought on the terms of purchase ?
tgt_text.4365: If I had wanted them to set on table, I should have tried to get them for nothing, no doubt.
tgt_text.4366: Why, then, do you not accuse me in like manner on many other points ?
tgt_text.4367: For many a time have I, for money, purchased wine, vegetables, fruit, and bread.
tgt_text.4368: Why, if you carry out this prin­ ciple, you prescribe starvation to all purveyors of dainties.
tgt_text.4369: For who will dare to make purchase of them, if it is looked upon as a matter of course, that all eatables that are procured with money are wanted, not for food, but for the purposes of magic ?
tgt_text.4370: But if there is no suspicion whatever existing, either in con­ sequence of the fact of fishermen being induced, for a sum of money, to do that which they are in the general habit of do- in-, namely, catching fish—(they have taken care, however, to summon none of these fishermen as witnesses, for the best of reasons, because none such there were )-nor yet of the fact of a price being given for a marketable commodity—(the amount of which price, however, they have taken care not to state, for fear lest, if they had named a moderate price, their story might have met with contempt, and, if an exorbitant one, it might not have been believed) ;
tgt_text.4371: if, on these points, I say, no ground for suspicion exists, then let JEmilianus answer me, on what evident grounds was he induced to make this charge of magical practices ? "
tgt_text.4372: You endeavoured to procure some fish," says he.
tgt_text.4373: I do not wish to deny the fact.
tgt_text.4374: But tell me, I beg of you, is he who endeavours to procure some fish a magician ?
tgt_text.4375: For my own part, I don't think he is a bit the more so than if he were in search of hares, or boars, or fowl.
tgt_text.4376: Or is it that fishes alone are in possession of certain pro­ perties that are hidden from other people, but known to ma­ gicians ?
tgt_text.4377: If you know what this property is, then it is clear that you yourself are a magician;
tgt_text.4378: but if you do not know it, then you must, of necessity, confess that you are accusing a person of a thing about which you know nothing whatever.
tgt_text.4379: Are you, then, so unversed in all literature, Day, in all the stories of the vulgar, that you cannot so much as coin these fictions of yours with some air of probability ?
tgt_text.4380: For how should a lumpish and chilly fish, or anything that is found in the sea, be able to kindle the flames of desire ?
tgt_text.4381: But perhaps you were induced to frame this falsehood from the circum­ stance that Venus is said to have arisen from the sea.
tgt_text.4382: Take note, if you please, Tannonius Pudens, of how much you were ignorant, when you undertook to prove the practice of magic from the procuring of fish.
tgt_text.4383: Had you been a reader of Virgil, you certainly would have known that other things are usually sought for such purposes.
tgt_text.4384: For, so far as I recollect, that poet enumerates fillets of soft wool, unctuous vervain, male frank­ incense, and threads of various colours;
tgt_text.4385: besides crackling laurel, clay that hardens, and wax that liquefies, as well as some other things, which he has described in his more serious work.* “ She sprinkles round, With feign'd Avernian drops, the hallow'd ground, Culls hoary simples, found by Phœbe's light, With brazen sickles reap'd at noon of night;
tgt_text.4386: Then mixes baleful juices in a bowl, And cuts the forehead of a newborn foal, Robbing the mother's love.
tgt_text.4387: "But you, libeller of the fishes, attribute far different appli- ances to magicians;
tgt_text.4388: substances not to be torn off from tender foreheads, but to be cut away from scaly backs;
tgt_text.4389: not to be dug up from the ground, but to be drawn up from the sea;
tgt_text.4390: not to be cropped with the sickle, but to be hooked up with the fisher's barb.
tgt_text.4391: In fine, for the purpose of incantations, he makes men­ tion of poisons, you of dainties, he of herbs and suckers, you of scales and bones;
tgt_text.4392: he culls from the meadow, you ransack the deep.
tgt_text.4393: I could also have quoted to you similar passages from Theocritus, others, again, from Homer, and a great num­ ber from Orpheus, and I could have repeated a multitude of lines from the Greek comedies and tragedies, as well as from the historians, had I not already observed that you were un­ able to read the letter of Pudentilla, because it was written in Greek.
tgt_text.4394: I will therefore just dip into one more Latin poet:
tgt_text.4395: here are the lines, which those will easily recognise who have read Laevius:
tgt_text.4396: * " Look for your antidote it on every side
tgt_text.4397: They snatch up charms of all sorts, whirling rhombs, Of magic potency;
tgt_text.4402: from the neighing colt Torn is the stimulant ‡ of fierce desire."
tgt_text.4403: If you had had any acquaintance with literature, you would have framed your fictions with much more probability, if you had stated that I had sought for these and other things;
tgt_text.4404: for perhaps, in consequence of the stories so universally spread about them, some credit would have then attached to your mention of these particulars.
tgt_text.4405: But when a fish is caught, what is it good for except to be cooked and served up at table ?
tgt_text.4406: but for magic it is of no avail.
tgt_text.4407: I will state to you my reasons for thinking so.
tgt_text.4408: Many have supposed that Pythagoras was a follower of Zoroaster, and was, like him, skilled in magic, and have informed us in their writings, that when in the vicinity of Metapontum, on the shores of his own part of Italy which he had made a kind of second Greece, § he saw a seine drawn up by certain fisher- men, whereupon he purchased the chances of the haul;
tgt_text.4409: and that after he had paid the money, he immediately gave orders that the fish which had been caught should be released from the nets, and returned to the deep.
tgt_text.4410: Now, I suppose, he would not have let them go out of his hands, if he had found in them anything useful for magical purposes.
tgt_text.4411: For this man, so well versed in all learning, and so close an imitator of the ancients, remembered full well that Homer, a poet gifted with universal knowledge, had, in his writings, attributed all the power of drugs to the earth, and not to the sea;
tgt_text.4412: for when speaking of a certain enchantress, he writes thus:
tgt_text.4413: " These drugs, so friendly to the joys of life, Bright Helen learned from Thone's imperial wife, Who swayed the sceptre, where prolific Nile With various simples clothes the fatten'd soil;
tgt_text.4414: With wholesome herbage mix'd, the direful bane Of vegetable venom taints the plain."*
tgt_text.4415: And so likewise in another passage:
tgt_text.4416: " Thus while he spoke, the sovereign plant he drew, Where on th' all-bearing earth unmark'd it grew."t
tgt_text.4417: While, on the other hand, you will never find in his writings either that Proteus drugged his changing figure with any marine and fishy substance, or Ulysses the trench, J Bolus the bag, Helen the goblet, Circe the cup, or Venus her girdle.
tgt_text.4418: Why, you are the only people to be found in the memory of man who, forming, as it were, a kind of hodge-podge of the productions of nature, make nothing of transferring the virtues of herbs, and roots, and suckers, and pebbles from the tops of mountains to the depths of the sea, and there sewing them up in the bellies of fishes.
tgt_text.4419: Hence, just as Mercury, the con­ veyer of incantations, Venus, the charmer of the soul, Luna, the looker-on in the night, and Trivia, the mistress of the shades, used to be summoned to the ceremonies of the magi­ cians ;
tgt_text.4420: so, according to your account, henceforth Neptune, in company with Salacia, and Portumnus, and the whole throng of the Nereids, will have been transferred from the surging agi­ tations of the waves to the agitations of passionate desire.
tgt_text.4421: I have now stated why, in my opinion, there is nothing in common between magicians and fishes.
tgt_text.4422: But now, if you think proper, let us believe, Æmilianus, that fishes really are in the habit of promoting magical influences.
tgt_text.4423: Does it, then, follow, as a necessary consequence, that whoever seeks for a fish is a magician ?
tgt_text.4424: By the same rule, the person who tries to procure a light cutter is a pirate, he who looks for a crow-bar is a housebreaker, and he who seeks a sword is a cut-throat.
tgt_text.4425: Nothing of ever so harmless a nature can you mention, but may possibly be used to man's disadvantage;
tgt_text.4426: and nothing, of ever so pleasing a tendency, but may be taken in bad part.
tgt_text.4427: Yet it is not, for all that, a necessary consequence that all things should obtain an utterly bad reputation;
tgt_text.4428: as, for instance, that you should suppose that frankincense, and cassia, and myrrh, and such other aromatics, are only bought for the pur­ pose of being used at funerals, seeing that they are also used in medical preparations, and in sacrifices.
tgt_text.4429: But, according to this mode of reasoning about fish, you would suppose that the companions of Menelaiis, too, were magicians, inasmuch as the greatest of poets says that at the island of Pharos they banished hunger by using curved hooks.
tgt_text.4430: In the same class, too, you will have to place sea-gulls, dol­ phins, and cray-fish;
tgt_text.4431: and then all epicures, too, who pur­ chase largely of fishermen;
tgt_text.4432: and even the fishermen them­ selves, who, in pursuit of their calling, seek for all kinds of fish. "
tgt_text.4433: Why, then," say you, " do you try to procure them ?"
tgt_text.4434: Really I do not choose, nor do I deem it necessary, to tell you ;
tgt_text.4435: but show me, I beg of you, if you possibly can, that I have tried to procure fish for those purposes you state.
tgt_text.4436: Sup­ pose I had bought hellebore, hemlock, or the juice of poppies, and other things, the use of which, in moderation, is conducive to health, but which, when mixed or taken in large quan­ tities, are dangerous;
tgt_text.4437: who could with common patience have endured it, if you had accused me of poisoning, because by means of these things a man may lose his life ?
tgt_text.4438: Let us see, however, what were the different kinds of fishes which were so necessary for me to possess, and so rarely to be met with, as to deserve to be sought for on the promise of a reward.
tgt_text.4440: in one they were mistaken, while the other two they invented.
tgt_text.4441: They were mistaken in saying thaf the fish was a sea-hare, for it was quite a different kind of fish altogether;
tgt_text.4442: one which my servant Themiso, a person by no means ignorant of the medical art, as you have heard from his own lips, brought to me quite unasked, for me to look at;
tgt_text.4443: for the fact is, that he has not even yet managed to find a sea-hare.

tgt_text.4643: Then besides, the wheel, when whirled round by the potter, readily affects with vertigo a person suffering from this ma­ lady, so much does the sight of the rotatory motion affect his debilitated spirits;
tgt_text.4644: so that a potter is much better able than a magician to cause the epileptic to fall prostrate.
tgt_text.4645: You have asked, and for no purpose, that I should produce the servants;
tgt_text.4646: I ask, and not for no purpose, that you will mention by name the witnesses who were present at these ne.

tgt_text.4648: Only one young lad, after all, do you name, this Sicinius Pudens here, in whose name you accuse me;
tgt_text.4649: he declares that he was present;
tgt_text.4650: but even if his boyhood did not in the slightest degree detract from his credibility with the court, still his position as accuser would impair the value of his testimony.
tgt_text.4651: It would have been much easier, .,Emilianus, and would have carried much greater weight, if you had said you yourself were present, and that in consequence of these rites you were first attacked with insanity, rather than entrust all this business, as though it were a mere joke, to boys..
tgt_text.4652: A boy fell down,-a boy saw him fall down,-and may not some boy have acted the enchanter too ?
tgt_text.4653: Tannonius Pudens here, craftily enough, when he perceived that this lying fiction also fell cold and harmless, and that it was all but hissed outright, as­ serted that he would produce some other boys who had also been enchanted by me, that thus at least, by raising your ex­ pectations, he might lull the suspicions of some among you;
tgt_text.4654: and then he passed on to another head of his argument.
tgt_text.4655: Now, although I might very well have taken no notice of this, still, as I have challenged him to proof on all other points, so I volunteer to do on this.
tgt_text.4656: For I long for these boys to be produced, who, I hear, have been encouraged to give false evidence against me, through hopes held out to them that they shall thereby gain their liberty.
tgt_text.4657: However, no more do I say than this:
tgt_text.4659: I demand, Tan­ nonius Pudens, and insist that you will fulfil the promise you have made.
tgt_text.4660: Produce these boys, in whom you have put such confidence;
tgt_text.4661: inform us what are their names ;
tgt_text.4662: a portion of the time that has been allotted for my own speech I give you leave to employ for the purpose.
tgt_text.4666: why cast your eyes on the ground ?
tgt_text.4667: If he does not know what it is he has said, or if he has forgotten the names, then do you, Æmili­ anus, step this way;
tgt_text.4668: say what were the instructions you gave to your counsel;
tgt_text.4670: what makes you turn so pale ?
tgt_text.4672: Is this the way to bring an accusation of such magnitude ?
tgt_text.4673: to make a laughing-stock of Claudius Maximus, a man of such exalted station, and to per­ secute me with your calumnious charges?
tgt_text.4674: But if, perchance, your advocate did make a slip, and if you have no.
tgt_text.4675: such boys to produce, at all events employ, fot some purpose or other, the fourteen servants whom I have brought here;
tgt_text.4676: or else why was it that you required such a large household to be brought into court ?
tgt_text.4677: Accusing me of magic, you have given me notice to produce fifteen servants.
tgt_text.4678: If you had accused me of acts of violence, how many servants, pray, would you have demanded ?
tgt_text.4679: Is it, then, that the fifteen servants know all about it, and yet it is a secret ?
tgt_text.4680: or is it no secret at all, and yet an affair of magic ?
tgt_text.4681: One of these two things you must necessarily confess;
tgt_text.4682: either that what I did was not unlawful, since I did not fear to allow so many per­ sons to be privy to it, or else that if it was unlawful, so many witnesses ought not to have been privy to it.
tgt_text.4683: This magic, from all I can learn, is a thing denounced by the laws, and from the remotest times forbidden by the Twelve Tables, in consequence of the incredible blasting of standing corn by means of incantations.
tgt_text.4684: Consequently, it is a thing no less secret in its practices than foul and abominable;
tgt_text.4685: it is gene­ rally carried on by night, hidden in deep gloom, removed from all observation, and effected by whispered spells:
tgt_text.4686: a process at which few, not to say slaves, but even free men, are allowed to be present.
tgt_text.4687: Do you want to make out that fifteen servants were present as spectators ?
tgt_text.4688: Was it a wedding, then, or some other cere­ monial, or an afternoon carousal ?
tgt_text.4689: Fifteen servants are here taking part in these magic rites, just like so many Quinde­ cemvirs,* elected for the performance of sacred duties.
tgt_text.4690: But to what end should I have employed so large a number, if the privity of but one is far more than is requisite ?
tgt_text.4692: why, that makes a whole borough.t
tgt_text.4695: the same number, if placed in chains, would fill a whole gaol;
tgt_text.4696: t or was it that such a multitude as this was necessary to hold the victims for sacrifice ?
tgt_text.4697: But all the while you have mentioned no victims except hens.
tgt_text.4698: Or were they required to count the grains of frankincense t or to knock down Thallus ?
tgt_text.4699: You stated, besides, that a free-born woman had been brought to my house, afflicted with the same malady as Thallus;
tgt_text.4700: that I promised to cure her, and that she, too, fell to the ground enchanted by me.
tgt_text.4701: So far as I can see, you have come here to charge me with being a wrestler, and not a magician, seeing that you assert in this fashion that all who have come near me have been levelled with the ground.
tgt_text.4702: How­ ever, upon being questioned by you, Maximus, Themiso, the doctor, by whom the woman was brought for me to examine, denied that anything whatever happened to her, except that I put the question, whether there was a ringing in her ears, and if so, in which of them in the greatest degree?
tgt_text.4703: upon which she made answer, that her right ear was very much dis­ turbed by it, and immediately after took her departure.
tgt_text.4704: And here, Maximus, although at the present moment I am careful to refrain from praising you, that I may not appear to flatter you with a view to this trial, still I cannot forbear from praising your acuteness in cross-examination.
tgt_text.4705: For just now, when these matters were discussed, and they asserted that the woman was enchanted, whilst the doctor, who was present, denied it, you very sagaciously enquired, what I was to gain by thus bewitching her;
tgt_text.4706: on which they answered, that the woman should fall to the ground. "
tgt_text.4707: Well, what then?" you asked, " did she die ?"
tgt_text.4708: They said no. " How then," say you, " what advantage would it have been to Apuleius if she fell?"
tgt_text.4709: For to this effect did you fairly and perseveringly put the question to them as many as three several times, be­ cause you well knew that the motives for all actions ought most carefully to be enquired into, and that often, when facts are admitted, the causes of them become subjects for enquiry;
tgt_text.4710: and you were aware that for this very reason the advocates of persons engaged in suits at law have the name given to them of " causidici," because it is their province to explain the causes for which each thing has been done.
tgt_text.4711: But, on the other hand, to deny that a thing has been done is an easy matter, and needs the services of no advocate whatever;
tgt_text.4712: while to show that it has been done rightfully or wrongfully is a most arduous and difficult task.
tgt_text.4713: It is useless, then, to enquire whether a thing has been done, which has had no evil cause to prompt its being done.
tgt_text.4714: Hence it is, that he who is accused before a conscientious judge of having done a thing, is free from all fears of enquiry, if he has had no reason for doing what was wrong.
tgt_text.4715: Now, since they have neither proved that the woman was enchanted, nor yet that she was thrown to the ground, and as I do not deny that, at the request of a medical man, she was examined by me, I will tell you, Maximus, why I did make the enquiry about the ringing in the ears ;
tgt_text.4716: and I shall do so, not so much for the sake of exculpating myself in this affair, which you have already pronounced to have nothing in it of faultiness or criminality, as because I would not wish to be silent on any matter that is suited to your ears and your learn­ ing.
tgt_text.4717: I will state it, then, as succinctly as possible, seeing that you are to be put in mind only, not instructed by me.
tgt_text.4718: The philosopher Plato, in that most celebrated dialogue of his, entitled " Timæus," after having, with a sort of celestial eloquence, explained the structure of the entire universe, most ingeniously discussed the threefold powers of our mind, and aptly shown why our several parts were formed by the Divine Providence, proceeds to range the causes of all maladies under three heads.
tgt_text.4719: The first cause he attributes to the elements of our bodies, in cases where the qualities of those elements, being the moist and the cold, and the two qualities that are their opposites, do not agree the one with the other;
tgt_text.4720: and this takes place when any one of them has exceeded its limits, or has shifted from its proper locality.
tgt_text.4721: The next cause of maladies exists in the corruption of those parts which are formed by a coalition of simple elements, united so as to form a single sub­ stance ;
tgt_text.4722: these are, for instance, blood, flesh, bones, and marrow;
tgt_text.4723: and then those parts, which are formed from a mixture of these several substances.
tgt_text.4724: In the third place, there are in the body collections of various coloured bile, and of restless and flatulent wind, and gross humours, all which are most frequent causes of diseases.
tgt_text.4725: In the number of these last is especially to be found the primary cause of the falling-sickness, about which I purposed to speak.
tgt_text.4726: For the flesh, through a noxious degree of heat, sometimes deliquesces into a moist state, that is, dense and cloggy, and a certain flatulency rises therefrom, in consequence of the heat of the compressed air, and a corrupt matter of whitish and frothy appearance flows from it.
tgt_text.4727: Now, this cor rupt matter, if it can find a vent to ooze forth from the body, is ejected with more unseemliness than danger.
tgt_text.4728: For it marks the exterior of the skin with leprosy, and variegates it with all kinds of spots;
tgt_text.4729: the person, however, to whom this happens is never afterwards attacked by epilepsy;
tgt_text.4730: and thus it is that a most afflicting malady of the mind is compensated by a slight disfigurement of the body.
tgt_text.4731: But, on the other hand, if these pernicious secretions are held in check, and become united with the black bile, these, raging at large, penetrate through all the vessels;
tgt_text.4732: and when they have done this, making their way towards the crown of the head, they mingle their destructive humours with the brain;
tgt_text.4733: and instantly affect that regal portion of the under­ standing which, all-important as it is in the reasoning facul­ ties, has fixed its seat in the head of man as its citadel and its palace.
tgt_text.4734: For its divers passages and its paths that lead to wis­ dom, these humours clog up and overwhelm;
tgt_text.4735: this, however, they do with less work during the hours of sleep, as at such times the patient, being filled with food and drink, only suffers from a slight attack of impeded respiration, which is a symptom of epilepsy.
tgt_text.4736: But if the humours increase to such a degree as even to attack the head while the patient is awake, then, a cloud suddenly comes across the spirit, he becomes torpid, the breath ceases, and the body falls to the ground, like that of a dead person.
tgt_text.4737: This our forefathers styled, not only the "major" and the " comitial," but also the " divine" disease;
tgt_text.4738: just as the Greeks, with good reason, have styled it ίερα νοσὸς, inasmuch as it attacks especially the reasoning parts of the mind, which are by far its most holy portion.
tgt_text.4739: You see, then, Maximus, what is the theory of Plato, which I have explained as perspicuously as I could, considering the time allowed me;
tgt_text.4740: and as I believe with him, that the Divine disease [or epilepsy] proceeds from these bad humours mounting to the head, it is clear I had good reason to make the enquiry, did this woman's head ache, was her neck torpid and stiff, and was there a throbbing in her temples, and a tingling in her ears ?
tgt_text.4741: And, what is still more, inasmuch as she admitted that she had a repeated ring­ ing in the right ear, that was a clear sign that the malady had taken a deep root.
tgt_text.4742: For as the right side of the body is the strongest, the less hope of recovery is there left, when even that gives way to disease.
