tgt_text.5684: The crowd, however, of the ignorant, who are rejected by Philosophy as uninitiated, whose notions of holiness are misplaced, who are deprived of genuine reason, who are destitute of religion;
tgt_text.5685: and incapable of grasping the truth, dishonour the Gods, either by a worship most over acted, or a most insolent disdain of them;
tgt_text.5686: one part being always in alarm through superstition, while the other is always swelling with contempt.
tgt_text.5687: Very many there are who venerate all these Gods, established in the lofty heights of the firmament, and far removed from human contagion :
tgt_text.5688: but not in such manner as they ought:
tgt_text.5689: all fear them, but through ignorance;
tgt_text.5690: a few deny their existence, but in a spirit of im­ piety.
tgt_text.5691: Plato thought these Gods to be incorporeal* and ani­ mated natures without an end.
tgt_text.5692: or beginning, but eternal both with reference to time past and time to come;
tgt_text.5693: spontaneously separated from the contact of the body by the nature peculiar to themselves;
tgt_text.5694: through perfection of intellect possessing su­ preme beatitude;
tgt_text.5695: good, not through participation in any ex­ traneous good, but of themselves;
tgt_text.5696: and able to procure for themselves every thing requisite, with a facilitywhich is prompt, simple, unrestrained, and absolute.
tgt_text.5697: But of the parent of these, who is the lord and author of all things, and who is free from all obligations to act or to suffer, not being bound by any necessity to the performance of any duties, why should I now begin to speak ?
tgt_text.5698: For Plato, who was endowed with a heavenly eloquence, discoursing in lan­ guage worthy of the immortal Gods, frequently proclaims that on account of the incredible and ineffable transcendency of his majesty, he cannot possibly be even in the slightest degree com­ prehended, under any definition, through the poverty of human language;
tgt_text.5699: and that the intellectual apprehension of this God can hardly flash upon wise men, when they have separated them- selves from body, as much as possible, through the vigour of the intellect;
tgt_text.5700: and that sometimes this knowledge does blaze forth with a most instantaneous flash, like a dazzling light amid the most profound darkness.*
tgt_text.5701: I will therefore omit the discussion of this theme, for which all words adequate to the amplitude of the subject are not only wanting to me, but could not even be found by my master Plato.
tgt_text.5702: Hence I shall at once sound a retreat, as to things which very far surpass my humble powers, and at length bring down my discourse from heaven to earth, in which we men are the principal animated things, though most of us, through the neglect of training, are so depraved, and are so imbued with all errors and the most atrocious crimes, and have become so utterly ferocious, through having nearly quite abandoned the mildness of our nature, that it may seem there is not an animal on the earth more vile than man.
tgt_text.5703: But at present our object is not to discuss feelings, but to treat of the natural distribution of things.
tgt_text.5704: Men, therefore, dwell on the earth, possessing the gift of speech, having immortal souls, but mortal members, with fri­ volous and anxious minds, with bodies brutish and infirm, of dissimilar manners, but similar errors, of presumptuous auda­ city, long-lived hope, labouring in vain, with variable for­ tunes, severally mortal, but taken altogether in their whole species, eternal, quitting the scene in regular succession, and leaving offspring to supply their place, fleeting in their time, tardy at gaining wisdom, speedy in meeting with death, and dis­ satisfied in life.
tgt_text.5705: You have, then, in the meantime, two kinds of animated beings, Gods entirely differing from men, in the sublimity of their abode, in the eternity of their existence, in the perfection of their nature, and having no proximate com­ munication with them;
tgt_text.5706: † since those that are supreme are separated from the lowest habitations by such a vast interval of distance;
tgt_text.5707: and life is there eternal and never-failing, but here decaying and interrupted, and the natures are there subli­ mated to beatitude, while those below are depressed to wretch­ edness.
tgt_text.5709: Has r ature connected itself by no bond, but allowed itself to be separated into the divine and human parts, and to be thus split and crippled, as it were ?
tgt_text.5710: For, as the same Plato remarks, "No God mingles with men."
tgt_text.5711: But this is the principal mark of their sublime nature, that they are not contaminated by any contact with us.*
tgt_text.5712: One part of them only is to be seen by us with our blunted vision;
tgt_text.5713: as the stars, about whose magnitude and colour men are still in doubt, while the rest are only known to our understandings, and that by no prompt perception.
tgt_text.5714: This, however, ought by no means to be wondered at with reference to the immortal Gods, since even among men, who are raised to opulence by the favour ot Fortune, and are elevated to the tottering throne and the un­ steady tribunal of a kingdom, access is rare, all beholders being kept at a distance, and they enjoy their dignity in re­ tirement;
tgt_text.5715: familiarity breeds contempt, t but privacy gains admiration."
tgt_text.5716: What, then, shall I do," some person may object, "after this very celestial, but almost inhuman decision of yours?
tgt_text.5717: if, so it is, that men are entirely removed from the immortal Gods, and are so exiled in these Tartarean realms of earth that all communica­ tion whatever with the heavenly Gods is denied them, and not one of the celestials occasionally visits them, as a shepherd visits his flocks of sheep, a groom his horses, or a herdsman his lowing cattle, in order that he may curb the more vicious, heal the diseased, and assist those which are in want ?
tgt_text.5718: No God, you say, interferes in human affairs.
tgt_text.5719: To whom, then, shall I ad­ dress my prayers ?
tgt_text.5720: To whom shall I make my vows ?
tgt_text.5722: Whom shall I invoke through­ out my whole life, as the helper of the unfortunate, the fa- vourer of the good, and the adversary of the wicked ?
tgt_text.5723: And whom, in fine, (a thing for which necessity most frequently occurs,) shall I adduce as a witness to my oath ?
tgt_text.5724: Am I to say, like Virgil's Ascanius,* " Now by this head I swear, by which before My father used to swear ?"
tgt_text.5725: Why, no doubt, Iulus, your father might use this oath among Trojans, who were allied to him by birth, and also perhaps among Greeks, who were known to him in battle;
tgt_text.5726: but among the Rutuli, who were but recently known by you, if no one believed in this head, what God would you have to be surety for you ?
tgt_text.5727: Would you have your right hand and your dart, like the ferocious Mezentius ?
tgt_text.5728: For these only, by which he defended himself, did he adjure:
tgt_text.5729: " For me ray right hand and the missile dart, Which now well-poised I hurl, are each a God."t
tgt_text.5730: Away, I beseech you, with such sanguinary Gods;
tgt_text.5731: a right hand weary with slaughter, and a dart rusted with gore.
tgt_text.5732: Neither of these is a fit object for you to adjure, nor that you should swear by them, for this is an honor that is peculiar to the highest of the Gods.
tgt_text.5733: For a solemn oath, as Ennius says, is also called Jovisjurandum.
tgt_text.5735: Am I to swear by Jupiter, in the shape of a stone, after the most ancient custom of the Romans ?
tgt_text.5736: Why, if the opinion of Plato is true, that God never mingles with men, a stone will hear me more easily than Jupiter.
tgt_text.5738: for Plato shall answer for his opinion in my words. "
tgt_text.5739: I do not affirm, " says he, " that the Gods are so far separated and alienated from us, that not even our prayers can reach them;
tgt_text.5740: for I have not removed them from attention to the affairs of mankind, but only from contact with them.
tgt_text.5741: "Besides, there are certain divine powers of a middle nature, situate in this interval of the air, between the highest ether and the earth below, through whom our aspirations and our deserts are conveyed to the Gods.
tgt_text.5742: These the Greeks call by name 11 dæmons," and, being placed as messengers between the inhabitants of earth and those of heaven, they carry from tho one to the other, prayers and bounties, supplications and as­ sistance, being a kind of interpreters and message carriers for both.
tgt_text.5743: Through these same demons, as Plato says in his Sym­ posium, all revelations, the various miracles of magicians, and all kinds of presages, are carried on.
tgt_text.5744: For specially appointed individuals of this number, administer everything according to the province assigned to each;
tgt_text.5745: either by framing dreams, or caus­ ing ominous fissures in entrails, or governing the flights of some birds, or instructing others in song, or inspiring prophets, or by launching thunders, or causing the lightning to flash in the clouds, or other things to take place means of which we obtain a know­ ledge of future events.
tgt_text.5746: And we have reason to believe that all these particulars are by the will, the power, and the authority of the celestial Gods, but through the obedience, aid, and ser­ vices of demons;
tgt_text.5747: for it was through the employment, the ser­ vices, and the care of these, that dreams forewarned Hannibal of the loss of one of his eyes;
tgt_text.5748: that inspection of the entrails foretold to Flaminius a perilous carnage;
tgt_text.5749: and that auguries assured to Attius Navius the miracle of the whetstone.
tgt_text.5750: Just in the same manner, tokens of future empire are imparted be­ forehand to certain persons;
tgt_text.5751: as, for instance, an eagle hovered over the cap on the head of Tarquinius Priscus, and a-flame shone from the head of Servius Tullius.
tgt_text.5752: And lastly, to these are owing all the presages of diviners, the expiatory sacrifices of the Etrurians, the sacrificial enclosure of places struck by light­ ning, and the verses of the Sibyls;
tgt_text.5753: all which, as I have said, are effected by certain influences that carry on the communica­ tion between men and Gods.
tgt_text.5754: Nor, indeed, would it be conformable to the majesty of the celestial Gods, that any one of them should either frame a dream for Hannibal, or withdraw the victim from Flaminius, or direct the flight of the bird for Attius Navius, or form in verse the predictions of the Sibyl, or be willing to snatch the hat from the head of Tarquin, and restore it, or place a splendid flame upon the head of Servius, but so as not to burn him.
tgt_text.5755: It is not becoming that the Gods of heaven should condescend to things of this nature.
tgt_text.5756: This is the pro­ vince of the intermediate Gods, who dwell in the regions of the air, which are adjacent to the earth, and on the confines of the heavens, just as in each part of the world there are animals peculiarly adapted to it, those which fly living in the air, and those which walk, on the earth.
tgt_text.5757: For since there are four ele­ ments universally known, nature being as it were divided into four grand portions, and there are animals peculiar to earth, water, and flame;
tgt_text.5758: (for Aristotle informs us that certain animals pecu­ liar thereto, and furnished with wings, fly about in burning furnaces, and pass the whole period of their existence in fire,* come to life therein, and with it die), and besides this, since, as we have already observed, so many stars are beheld floating above in æther, that is to say, in the very brightest heat of fire,†—since this is the case, why should nature suffer this fourth element, the air, which is so widely extended, to be the only one void of every thing, and destitute of its own inhabitants ?
tgt_text.5759: Why should not animated beings be generated in this air in the same manner as animals that exist in flame are generated in fire, animals that float, in water, and those of an earthly nature, on earth ?
tgt_text.5760: For you have every reason to pronounce his opinion false who assigns the birds to the air;
tgt_text.5761: for not one of them raises itself above the summit of Mount Olympus, which, though it is said to be the highest of all mountains, yet if you measure its height in a straight line, the distance to its summit is not equal, according to the opinions of geometricians, to ten stadia;
tgt_text.5762: whereas the immense mass of air extends as far as the nearest portion of the cycle of the moon, beyond which æther takes its rise in an upward direction.
tgt_text.5763: What, then, are we to say of such a vast body of air, which ranges in extent from the nearest part of the revo­ lutions of the moon as far as the highest summit of Mount Olympus ?
tgt_text.5764: Will that, pray, be destitute of its own appropriate animated beings, and will this part of nature be without life, and impotent?
tgt_text.5765: Moreover, if you attentively consider the matter, birds themselves may, with greater propriety, be said to be terrestrial than aerial animals;
tgt_text.5766: for their whole living is always on the earth;
tgt_text.5767: there they procure food, and there they rest;
tgt_text.5768: and they only make a passage through that part of the air in flying which lies nearest to the earth.
tgt_text.5769: But, when they are wearied by the rowing motion of their wings, the earth is to them as a harbour.
tgt_text.5770: If, therefore, reason evidently requires that its appropriate animals must also be admitted to exist in the air, it remains for us to consider what they arc, and what is their nature.
tgt_text.5771: They are then by no means animals of an earthly nature, for such have a downward tendency, through their gravity.
tgt_text.5772: But neither are they of a fiery nature, lest they should be carried aloft by their heat.
tgt_text.5773: A certain middle nature, there­ fore, must be conceived by us, in conformity to the middle position of their locality, that so the nature of the inhabitants may be conformable to the nature of the region.
tgt_text.5774: Well, then, let us form in our mind and generate in our ideas bodies so constituted as neither to be so sluggish as terrestrial, nor so light as ethereal, but in a certain measure distinct from both, or else composed of a mixture of both, either removed from, or modified by, a participation of both.
tgt_text.5775: They will, however, be more easily conceived, if admitted to be a mixture of both, than if they assumed to be mingled with neither.
tgt_text.5776: The bodies of these demons, therefore, must have some little weight, in order that they may not be carried aloft;
tgt_text.5777: and they must also have some lightness, in order that they may not be precipitated to the realms below.
tgt_text.5778: However, that I may not appear to you to be devising things that are incredible, after the manner of the poets, I will just give you an example of this equipoised middle nature.
tgt_text.5779: We see the clouds unite in a way not much different from this tenuity of body;
tgt_text.5780: but if these were equally light as those bodies which are entirely devoid of weight, they would never cap the heights of a lofty mountain with, as it were, certain wreathed chains, depressed beneath its ridges, as we frequently perceive they do.
tgt_text.5781: On the other hand, if they were naturally so dense and so ponderous that no union with a more active levity could elevate them, they would certainly strike against the earth, of their own tendency, just like a mass of lead and stone.
tgt_text.5782: As it is, however, being pendulous and moveable, they are guided in this direction and in that by the winds amid the sea of air, in the same manner as ships, shift- in- sometimes in proximity and remoteness;
tgt_text.5783: for, if they are teeming with the moisture of water, they are depressed downward, as though for the purpose of bringing forth.
tgt_text.5784: And on this account it is that clouds that are more moist descend lower, in dusky masses, and with a slower motion, while those that are serene ascend higher, and are impelled like fleeces of wool, in white masses, and with a more rapid flight.
tgt_text.5785: Have you not heard how Lucretius most eloquently expresses himself concerning thunder in his Sixth Book ? "
tgt_text.5786: The azure heavens with dreadful thunders shake.
tgt_text.5787: Because th' ethereal clouds, ascending high, Dash on each other, driven by adverse winds."
tgt_text.5788: But if the clouds fly aloft, all of which originate from the earth, and again flow downward to it, pray what should you conclude as to the bodies of demons, which are so much more attenuated in their composition ?
tgt_text.5789: For they are not heaped up from feculent vapours and dense mists, as is the nature of clouds, but they are formed of the most pure liquid and serene element of air, and on this account they are not visible on every occasion to the human eye, but only when by divine command they allow themselves to be seen.
tgt_text.5790: For in them no earthly density occupies the place of light, so as to encounter our perception, and necessarily to arrest our visual ray by that solidity;
tgt_text.5791: but the lineaments of the bodies which they have are rare, shining, and attenuated, to such a degree, that they allow all the rays of our vision to pass through them in consequence of their rarity, refract them by their bright­ ness, and baffle them by their subtlety.
tgt_text.5792: Hence that de­ scription of Minerva, in Homer, presenting herself in the midst of the assembly of the Greeks, for the purpose of check­ ing the wrath of Achilles.
tgt_text.5793: If you will wait a moment I will give you the Geeek line in Latin, and here it is on the spur of the moment.
tgt_text.5794: Minerva, then, as I said, by the command of Juno came, in order to moderate the wrath of Achilles, " Seen by him only, by the rest unseen." * Hence, also, Virgil's Juturna, when in the midst of many thou­ sands of men, for the purpose of aiding her brother, " With soldiers mingled, though by none perceived," t fully accomplishing that which the captain in Plautus boasted of having effected by his shield, " Which dazzled by its light the vision of his foes."
tgt_text.5795: And not to discuss prolixly the rest of the instances, the poets, from this multitude of demons, are accustomed, in a way by no means remote from the truth, to feign the Gods to be haters and lovers of certain men, and to give prosperity and promotion to some, and to oppose and afflict others.
tgt_text.5796: Hence, they are in­ fluenced by pity, moved by indignation, racked with vexation, elated with joy, and are subject to all the affections of the human mind;
tgt_text.5797: and are agitated by all the fluctuations of human thought, with similar commotions of the spirit and agitations of the feelings.*
tgt_text.5798: All which storms and tempests are far alien from the tranquil state of the celestial Gods.
tgt_text.5799: For all the celestials always enjoy the same state -of mind, with an eternal equanimity, which in them is never driven from its own fixed state either in the direction of pleasure or of pain;
tgt_text.5800: nor is it moved by any thing from its own everlasting rule, towards any sudden line of conduct;
tgt_text.5801: neither by any external force, because there is nothing more powerful than deity;
tgt_text.5802: nor of their own impulse, because nothing is more perfect than deity.
tgt_text.5803: And furthermore, how can he appear to have been per­ fect, who moves from a former condition of being to another condition which is better ?
tgt_text.5804: And this the more especially, as no one spontaneously embraces any thing new, unless he is tired of what he had before;
tgt_text.5805: for a new mode of proceeding cannot be adopted, without disapproving the preceding modes.
tgt_text.5806: Hence, it follows, that a God ought not to be employed in any temporal functions either of beneficence or love;
tgt_text.5807: and, therefore, is neither to be influenced by indignation nor by pity, nor to be disquieted by any anxiety, nor elated by any hilarity;
tgt_text.5808: but he is free from all the passions of the mind, so as never either to grieve or to rejoice, nor on sudden impulse to will or unwill.
tgt_text.5809: †But all these, and other qualities of the like kind, properly accord with the middle nature of demons.*
tgt_text.5810: For they are in­ termediate between us and the Gods, both in the place of their habitation, and in their nature ;
tgt_text.5811: having immortality in common with the Gods of heaven, and passions in common with sub­ ordinate beings.
tgt_text.5812: For they are capable, just as we are, of being affected by all that soothes as well as all that moves the mind;
tgt_text.5813: so as to be stimulated by anger, influenced by pity, allured by gifts, appeased by prayers, exasperated by affronts, soothed by ho­ nours, and swayed by all other circumstances, just in the same way that we are.
tgt_text.5814: For, to embrace the nature of them in a de­ finition, demons are as to genus animated beings, as to mind rational, as to feelings passive, as to body aerial, as to duration eternal.
tgt_text.5815: Of these five characteristics which I have mentioned, the three first are the same as those which we possess, the fourth is peculiar to themselves, and the last they possess in common with the immortal Gods, from whom they differ in being subject to passion.
tgt_text.5816: Hence, according to my idea, I have not absurdly called demons passive, because they are subject to the same perturbations as we are:
tgt_text.5817: and on this account it is that we may place some confidence in the different observances of religions, and the various propitiatory offerings made in sacred rites.
tgt_text.5818: There are likewise some among this number of Gods who rejoice in victims, or ceremonies, or observances, nocturnal or diurnal, public or performed in secret, replete with the greatest joy or marked with extreme sadness.
tgt_text.5819: Thus, the Egyptian deities are almost all of them delighted with lamentations, the Grecian in general with dances, and those of the Barbarians with the sound produced by cymbals, tambourines, and pipes.
tgt_text.5820: So. in like manner, other points relating to sacred rites present consider­ able diversities, according to different regions;
tgt_text.5821: as, for instance, the crowds that swell the sacred processions, the mysteries, the duties performed by the priests, and the observances per- formed by the devotees:
tgt_text.5822: and then, again, the images of the Gods, and their insignia, the rites performed in, and the situa­ tions of, their temples, and the variety of blood and colour in their victims.
tgt_text.5823: All these particulars are regulated and set forth in the accustomed form peculiar to the usage of each place, so much so that we have frequently ascertained by means of dreams, oracles and prophecies especially, that the Divinities have been indignant, if anything in their sacred rites has been neglected through slothfulness or contumacy;
tgt_text.5824: of which cir­ cumstances I have an abundance of examples.
tgt_text.5825: They are, how­ ever, so universally mentioned, and so generally known, that no one could attempt to recount them, without omitting a great number more than he mentioned.
tgt_text.5826: On this account, I shall desist for the present from expending words upon these parti.
tgt_text.5827: culars, which if they have not obtained assured credit with all men, still, at least, are universally within the knowledge of all.
tgt_text.5828: It will be more advisable, therefore, to discuss this point in the Latin tongue, that there are kinds of demons enumerated by the philosophers, in order that you may more clearly and more fully come to an understanding on the presage of Socrates, and his familiar demon.
tgt_text.5829: Now, according to a certain signification, the human soul, even when it is still situate in the body, is called a demon. " 0 say, Euryalus, do Gods inspire
tgt_text.5830: In minds this ardour, or does fierce desire Rule as a God in its possessor's breast ?"*
tgt_text.5831: If, then, this is the case, a longing of the soul that is of gooa tendency is a good demon.
tgt_text.5832: Hence it is that some think, as we have already observed, that the blessed are called ἐυδαίμονες, eudæmones, the demon of whom is good, that is, whose mind is perfect in virtue.
tgt_text.5833: You may call this demon in our language, according to my mode of interpretation, by the name of " Genius," whether quite correctly I am not altogether sure, but at all events, at any risk you may so call it;
tgt_text.5834: because this God, who is the mind of every one,† though immortal, is never- theless, after a certain manner, generated with man;
tgt_text.5835: so that those prayers in which we implore the Genius, and which we employ when we embrace the knees [genua] of those whom we supplicate, seem to me to testify this connexion and union, since they comprehend in two words the body and the mind, through the communion and conjunction of which we exist.
tgt_text.5836: There is also another species of demons, according to a se­ cond signification, and this is the human soul, after it has per­ formed its duties in the present life, and quitted the body:
tgt_text.5837: I find that this is called in the ancient Latin language by the name of Lemur.
tgt_text.5838: Now, of these Lemures, the one who, under­ taking the guardianship of his posterity, dwells in a house with propitious and tranquil influence, is called the "familiar" Lar.
tgt_text.5839: But those who, having no fixed habitation of their own, are punished with vague wandering, as with a kind of exile, on account of the evil deeds of their life, are usually called "Larvæ," thus becoming a vain terror to the good, but a source of punishment to the bad.
tgt_text.5840: But when it is uncertain what is the allotted condition of any one of these, and whether it is Lar or Larva, it is called a God Manes ;
tgt_text.5841: the name of God being added for the sake of honor.
tgt_text.5842: For those only are called Gods, who being of the number of the Lemures, and having regulated the course of their life justly and prudently, have afterwards been celebrated by men as divinities, and are uni­ versally worshipped with temples, and religious rites;
tgt_text.5843: such, for instance, as Amphiaraus in Boeotia, Mopsus in Africa, Osiris in Egypt, and others in other nations, but Esculapius every­ where.
tgt_text.5844: All this distribution, however, has been made of those demons, who once existed in a human body.
tgt_text.5845: But there is another species of demons, more exalted and august, not fewer in number, but far superior in dignity, who, being for ever liberated from the bonds and conjunction of the body, preside over certain powers.
tgt_text.5846: In the number of these are Sleep and Love, who possess powers of a different nature;
tgt_text.5847: Love, of exciting to wakefulness, Sleep of lulling to rest.
tgt_text.5848: From this more elevated order of demons, Plato is of opinion that a peculiar demon is allotted to every man, to be a witness and a guardian* of his conduct in life, who, without being visible to any one, is always present, and is an overseer not only of his actions, but even of his thoughts.
tgt_text.5849: But when life is finished, and THE SOUL has to return to its judges, then the demon who has presided over it immediately seizes, and leads it as his charge to judgment, and is there present with it while it pleads its cause;
tgt_text.5850: and censures it if it is guilty of any un­ truthfulness ;
tgt_text.5851: corroborates what it says, if it asserts what is true;
tgt_text.5852: and conformably to its testimony, sentence is passed.
tgt_text.5853: All you, therefore, who hear this divine opinion of Plato, as ex­ plained by me, so adapt your minds to whatever you may have to do, or to whatever may be the subject of your meditation, as men who know that there is nothing concealed from those guardians either within the mind or external to it;
tgt_text.5854: but that the demon scrupulously takes part in all these matters, sees all things, understands all things, and dwells in the most profound recesses of the mind, in the place of conscience. †
tgt_text.5855: He of whom I speak is entirely our guardian, our individual keeper, our watcher at home, our own proper regulator, a searcher into our inmost fibres, our constant observer, our in­ separable witness, a reprover of our evil actions, an approver of our good ones;
tgt_text.5856: if he is becomingly attended to, sedulously examined and devoutly worshipped, in the way in which he was worshipped by Socrates in justice and in innocence;
tgt_text.5857: he is our forewarner in uncertainty, our monitor in matters of doubt, our defender in danger, and our assistant in need.
tgt_text.5858: He is able also by dreams, and by tokens, and perhaps even openly, when necessity demands it, to avert from you evil, to increase your blessings, to aid you when depressed, to support you when falling, to lighten your darkness, to regulate your prosperity, and modify your adversity.
tgt_text.5859: What wonder, then, if Socrates, who was a man perfect in the highest degree, and wise even by the testimony of Apollo, should know and venerate this his God;
tgt_text.5860: and that hence, this Lar, his keeper, and nearly, as I may say, his co-mate and his domestic associate, should repel from him everything which ought to be repelled, foresee what ought to be foreseen, and forewarn him of what he ought to be forewarned of, if at any time, the functions of wisdom falling short, he stood in need, not of counsel, but foreknowledge;
tgt_text.5861: in order that when he was vacillating through doubt, he might take a firm stand through being forewarned.

tgt_text.6079: Now I would that in like manner, it were a valid decree of philosophy that no one should presumptuously attempt its likeness;

tgt_text.6096: since it is an arduous and very difficult thing to satisfy even the moderate expectations of a few, especially for me, whom my acquired reputation, and your favourable predisposition towards me, suffer not to utter any thing negligently, and without deep reflection.

tgt_text.6115: This Hippias was one of the sophists, superior to all in the number of the arts he knew, inferior to none in eloquence.
tgt_text.6116: He was contemporary with Socrates, a native of Elis, of what family is not known.
tgt_text.6117: His glory was great, his fortune small;
tgt_text.6118: but his genius was great, his memory excellent, his studies various, his rivals many.
tgt_text.6119: This Hippias came once to Pisa to the Olympic games, where he was not less remarkable for the ornaments he wore than for the fact that he had wrought them himself.
tgt_text.6120: Of all those things he had with him he had purchased not one, but had made them with his own hands;
tgt_text.6121: the garments in which he was clad, the shoes on his feet, and everything he carried on his person.
tgt_text.6122: For clothing he had an inner tunic of very fine texture, of triple thread, and double purple dye.
tgt_text.6123: He had wrought it single-handed at home.
tgt_text.6124: He was girt with a belt adorned with a sort of Babylonian pic­ ture of admirable colours.
tgt_text.6125: Nor had any one helped him in that work.
tgt_text.6126: His outer covering was a white cloak, which also is known to have been his own handiwork.
tgt_text.6127: Also he had put together the soles of his own foot gear;
tgt_text.6128: and as for the gold ring on his left hand, bearing a most skilfully cut seal which he often exhibited, he himself had rounded the ring, and had closed the pallet, and engraved the gem.
tgt_text.6129: I have not yet told all he did.
tgt_text.6130: For I shall not be loth to relate what he was not ashamed to display, who asserted in a large assembly that he had also made himself an oil flask which he carried about him, of a lenticular form, of a rounded outline and small convexity;
tgt_text.6131: and with it a neat little scraper to be used in the bath, with a convenient handle and tubulated face, so that it might be held steadily in the hand, and that the sweat might flow out of it in a stream.
tgt_text.6132: Who will not extol a man skilled in so many arts;
tgt_text.6133: illustrious for such manifold know­ ledge ;
tgt_text.6134: a Dædalus in the use of so many tools ?
tgt_text.6135: Certainly, I admire Hippias, but I would rather rival the fecundity of his genius in matters of learning, than in multitudinous appliances for personal use.
tgt_text.6136: I confess, indeed, that I am not expert in handicraft arts;
tgt_text.6137: that I buy my garments at the clothier's—these shoes at the shoe-maker's;
tgt_text.6138: that I wear no ring, and hold gems and gold of no more account than lead and pebbles ;
tgt_text.6139: that I buy a scraper, a flask, and other bath utensils at the shops.
tgt_text.6140: I am far from denying that I do not know how to use the loom, or the awl, or the file, or the lathe, or any such implements;
tgt_text.6141: instead of these, I confess I prefer to compose with a writing reed, poems of all kinds adapted to the laurel branch,* the lyre, the sock, the buskin;
tgt_text.6144: as, also, orations praised by the eloquent, and dia­ logues praised by philosophers;
tgt_text.6145: and to compose these and such like works, both in Greek and Latin, with two-fold study, with equal diligence and in similar style.
tgt_text.6146: These things I would, indeed, Proconsul, excellent man, that I could lay before you not singly and piece-meal, but collectively in one heap, and enjoy your honourable testimony regarding all my literary labours.
tgt_text.6147: It is not, indeed, from penury of fame that I de­ sire this, for fame has long subsisted for me, bright and un­ broken among all your predecessors,' down to yourself;
tgt_text.6148: but because by no one am I more desirous of being esteemed than by him which I justly esteem above all others.
tgt_text.6149: For it is a law of nature that whom you praise, him you also love;
tgt_text.6150: and moreover, whom you love, by him you would wish to be praised.
tgt_text.6151: Now I profess myself one who prizes you dearly, being bound to you by no private, but by all manner of public favours.
tgt_text.6152: I have, indeed, obtained nothing from you, for nothing have I asked.
tgt_text.6153: But philosophy has taught me to love not only kind­ ness but injury, and rather to do homage to reason than to seek my own advantage, and to prefer public expediency to my own.
tgt_text.6154: Hence, whilst the majority love the beneficial effects of your goodness, I love its principle.
tgt_text.6155: And this I have begun to do whilst considering your conduct in the affairs of the inha­ bitants of this province, for which they ought to love you intensely:
tgt_text.6156: such of them as have felt it in their own persons, for sake of the benefit they have received;
tgt_text.6157: such as have not personally experienced it for sake of the example.
tgt_text.6158: For you have benefited many individually, and all by your example.
tgt_text.6159: For who does not delight to learn from you by what adjust­ ment may be acquired that pleasant gravity of yours, that mild austerity, that placid firmness, that gracious vigour of mind.
tgt_text.6160: Never, to my knowledge, did the province of Africa ever revere more, and fear less any proconsul;
tgt_text.6161: in no year of administration but yours, had shame more power than fear towards restraining offences.

tgt_text.6186: The parrot is a bird of India, in form a little less than the dove;
tgt_text.6187: but its colour is not that of the dove, for it is not white, nor blackish, or yellowish on either side, or variegated;
tgt_text.6188: but the parrot's colour is green both in its inner down and its outer feathers, except that it is varied in the neck alone.
tgt_text.6189: For its neck is encompassed and girded with a red circle, like a gold necklace, and of equal splendour.
tgt_text.6190: Its beak is hard in the highest degree.
tgt_text.6191: When it swoops down from its highest flight upon a rock, it lights there upon its beak, and fixes itself as with an anchor.
tgt_text.6192: Its head too, is as hard as its beak.
tgt_text.6193: When it is compelled to imitate our speech, its head is beaten with a little iron rod, to make it attend to the commands of its master.
tgt_text.6194: This is the ferula beneath which it learns.
tgt_text.6195: Its schooling begins when it is but a chick, and continues until its second year, as long as its mouth is easy to mould, and its tongue is pliable.
tgt_text.6196: If taken old, it is indocile and forgetful.
tgt_text.6197: But that kind of parrot is apter to learn human speech which feeds on nuts, and which has feet with five toes like man;
tgt_text.6198: for all parrots have not that characteristic;
tgt_text.6199: but it is common to them all to have the tongue broader than that of other birds, whereby they more easily articulate human words, as having a more expanded plectrum and palate.
tgt_text.6200: But what it has learned it sings, or rather speaks, like us, so that if you heard it, you would suppose it was the voice of a man;
tgt_text.6201: but if you saw it, you would say it was not speaking, but trying to do so.
tgt_text.6202: Now both the crow and the parrot pronounce only what they have been taught.
tgt_text.6203: If you teach a parrot ribaldry, he will be a ribald, screaming scurrility day and night.
tgt_text.6206: When it has run through all the scurrilous phrases it has learned, it begins the same strain over again.
tgt_text.6207: If you would be free from its ribaldry, you must cut out its tongue, or at once send it back to its woods.
tgt_text.6208: For philosophy has not bestowed on me that kind of speech, as nature has endowed some birds with a brief and periodical song, a morning song to swallows, a mid-day to cicalas, an after­ noon to buzzards, an evening to screech owls, a nocturnal to homed owls, a peep of day song to cocks.
tgt_text.6209: All these creatures differ from each other in the period and the manner of their song;
tgt_text.6210: the cocks sing with an awakening strain, the homed owls moan, the screech owls are querulous, the buzzards have inflected notes, the cicalas are obstreperous, the swallows twitter shrilly.
tgt_text.6211: But the discourse of the philosopher is practised at all seasons, and is reverend to hear, useful to understand, and omnisonant in compass.
tgt_text.6212: Crates, the follower of Diogenes, who was adored like a domestic Lar by the Athenians of his time, was one against whom no door was ever shut;
tgt_text.6213: nor had any father of a family a secret so profound as not to admit the seasonable interposi­ tion of Crates, the analyser and arbitrator of all disputes and altercations between relations.
tgt_text.6214: As the poets relate that Hercules formerly quelled by his valour horrid monsters, both human and brute, so was that philosopher a Hercules against anger and envy, avarice and lust, and other monsters and enormities of the human mind.
tgt_text.6215: All these pests he drove out from the minds of men, purged families of them, and quelled malevolence.
tgt_text.6216: He, too, was half naked, and notable for his club;
tgt_text.6217: he was likewise a native of Thebes, whence Hercules is known to have derived his birth.
tgt_text.6218: Before he became downright Crates, he was numbered among the nobles of Thebes:
tgt_text.6219: his family was one of the best, his household numerous, his dwelling adorned with an ample vestibule.
tgt_text.6220: He himself was well dressed, and well endowed with lands.
tgt_text.6221: Afterwards he came to understand that no security was bequeathed him with his ' wealth that he should enjoy it all his life;
tgt_text.6222: that all things are unstable and insecure ;
tgt_text.6223: that all the riches under the sky avail nothing towards a happy life.
tgt_text.6224: When Crates learned these and similar truths, partly from Diogenes and partly from his own reflection, he at last went out into the forum, and threw down his wealth like a load of dung, more fatiguing than useful.
tgt_text.6225: Then when a great crowd had as­ sembled, he cried out, "Crates manumits Crates."
tgt_text.6226: Thence­ forth he lived happily all his days, not only without servants, but also bare and disencumbered of every thing.
tgt_text.6227: And so much was he sought after, that a noble virgin, scorning younger wooers, voluntarily chose him for her own.
tgt_text.6228: And when Crates uncovered his shoulders and showed how he was hunchbacked, and laid his wallet and staff and his cloak on the ground, tell­ ing her that these were his worldly gear, and that such as she had seen was his beauty, and bidding her therefore ponder carefully, that she might not find reason to complain after­ wards, Hipparche still accepted the proposed conditions.
tgt_text.6229: She replied that she had already sufficiently considered the matter;
tgt_text.6230: that she could nowhere in the world find a richer or a hand- somer husband;
tgt_text.6231: and he might therefore take her where he pleased.
tgt_text.6232: The cynic led her to the portico, and there lay with her in a frequented spot, publicly in broad daylight;
tgt_text.6233: and he would have deflowered her in all men's sight, prepared as she was to bear it with equal indifference, had not Zeno con­ cealed his master from the gaze of the surrounding throng, by hanging his tattered cloak before him.
tgt_text.6234: Samos is an island of moderate extent in the Icarian Sea, opposite Miletus, situated to the westward of it, and separated from it by no great breadth of sea.
tgt_text.6235: Passing with easy sail from one to the other, the second day puts you in port.
tgt_text.6236: The soil of the island is inapt for corn, unfit for the plough, more productive of olives, nor is it dug by the vinegrower or the gardener.
tgt_text.6237: Its whole cultivation consists in hoeing and plants ing rows of olives, from the produce of which the island is more fructiferous than frugiferous.*
tgt_text.6238: Furthermore, it abounds in inhabitants, and is much frequented by strangers.
tgt_text.6239: It has a town by no means corresponding to its reputation;
tgt_text.6240: but that it was once large is shown by the ruins of walls in many places.
tgt_text.6241: There stands the most celebrated temple of JUDO.
tgt_text.6242: It stands near the sea-shore, at a distance, if I remember rightly, of not more than twenty stadia from the town.
tgt_text.6243: It contains a most opulent shrine of the goddess, and a vast quantity of silver in platters, mirrors, cups, and such like utensils.
tgt_text.6244: There is also a great amount of bronze, in various figures, of very ancient and handsome workmanship.
tgt_text.6245: For instance, there is before the altar a statue of Bathyllus, dedicated by the tyrant Polycrates, than which I do not think I have seen anything more exquisite.
tgt_text.6246: Some erroneously suppose it to be the statue of Pythagoras.
tgt_text.6247: It is a youth of remarkable beauty, with hair parted on the forehead, and falling evenly on the cheeks;
tgt_text.6248: but behind the hair is longer, and covers the neck, which shines through them as far as the verge of the shoulders.
tgt_text.6249: The neck is plump, the cheeks round and beardless, and there is a little dimple in the chin;
tgt_text.6250: the costume is exactly that of a harper ;
tgt_text.6251: he looks towards the goddess like one who is singing;
tgt_text.6252: he wears a figured and coloured tunic, flowing down to his feet, with a zone in the Greek fashion;
tgt_text.6253: and a chlamys covering both arms to the wrists.
tgt_text.6254: The other histrionic ornaments hang upon the figure.

tgt_text.6257: the left is stretched out, and touches the strings with its spread fingers;
tgt_text.6258: the right applies the plectrum to the lyre, as if ready to strike the chords when the voice has paused in singing.
tgt_text.6259: Meanwhile he seems to pour out his song from his rounded mouth, with lips inten­ tionally half opened.
tgt_text.6260: Now this is the statue of a certain youth beloved by Polycrates, the tyrant, whom Anacreon, the Teian, celebrates in song for friendship's sake.
tgt_text.6261: But it is far from being the statue of Pythagoras, the philosopher.
tgt_text.6262: The latter was by birth a Samian, most remarkable for beauty, deeply versed in minstrelsy and all kinds of music, and he lived about the time when Polycrates ruled in Samos.

tgt_text.6264: Just after the latter had began to rule, Pythagoras fled privily from the island, having lately lost his father Mnesarchus, whom I find to have been an artist, and to have acquired reputation rather than wealth, by very cleverly en­ graving gems.
tgt_text.6265: Some say that Pythagoras was at that time conveyed to Egypt among the captives of king Cambyses, and that he had for teachers the Persian magi, and especially Zo­ roaster, the adept in every divine mystery;
tgt_text.6266: and that he was afterwards received by a certain Gillus, a leading man among the inhabitants of Crotona.
tgt_text.6267: But the more generally received story is, that he went of his own accord to acquire the learn­ ing of Egypt, and that he was there taught by the priests the incredible powers of ceremonies, the wonderful commutations of numbers, and the most ingenious figures of geometry;
tgt_text.6268: but that not satisfied with these mental accomplishments, he afterwards visited the Chaldæans and the Brahmins, and among the latter the Gymnosophists.
tgt_text.6269: The Chaldæans taught him the stars, the definite orbits of the planets, and the various effects of both kinds of stars upon the nativity of men;
tgt_text.6270: as also, for much money, the remedies for human use derived from the earth, and the air, and the sea.
tgt_text.6271: But the Brahmins taught him the greater part of his philosophy:
tgt_text.6272: what are the rules and principles of the understanding;
tgt_text.6273: what the functions of the body;
tgt_text.6274: how many are the faculties of the soul, how many the mutations of life;
tgt_text.6275: what torments or rewards devolve upon the souls of the dead according to their respective deserts.
tgt_text.6276: Moreover, there was Pherecydes, a native of the island of Syros, who was the first who ventured to reject the fetters of verse, and to write in prose:
tgt_text.6277: him, too, Pythagoras waited on as another master, and when turned into a scab of creeping things by the corruption of a most horrible disease, he buried him religiously.
tgt_text.6278: He is said also to have discussed natural science under Anaximander, the Milesian;
tgt_text.6279: to have followed for instruction Epimenides, of Crete, the illustrious seer and poet;
tgt_text.6280: and likewise Leodamas, the disciple of Creophylus, which latter is said to have been the host of the poet Homer, and his imitator in song.
tgt_text.6281: Instructed by so many masters, having drunk of so many various fountains of knowledge all over the world, this man of surpassingly mighty genius, and of more than human grandeur of soul, the first namer and founder of philosophy, taught his disciples nothing in the first place but to be silent.
tgt_text.6282: With him the first study imposed upon the future sage was to hold his tongue altogether, and as for the words which poets call winged, to pluck their plumes and shut them up within the walls of his white teeth.
tgt_text.6283: This was, I say, absolutely the first rudiment of wisdom, to learn to think, and unlearn to prate.
tgt_text.6284: But they did not abstain from speaking all their lives long, nor did all follow their master in silence during an equally long period;
tgt_text.6285: but silence observed during a short space of time was thought enough for men of graver disposition, whilst the more talkative were punished by a silence of five years, their voice being sent, as it were, into exile.
tgt_text.6286: Now our master, Plato, imitates Pythagoras, differing in little or no de­ gree from his sect.
tgt_text.6287: I, too, among a great many men, having been admitted into his sect by my teachers, have learned both these things in academic meditations :
tgt_text.6288: to speak with all my might when speech is required ;
tgt_text.6289: and when silence is required, to hold my tongue willingly.
tgt_text.6290: Through this moderation I think I have obtained credit from all your predecessors, not less for my opportune silence, than for my timely speaking.
tgt_text.6291: Before I begin, noblemen of Africa, to thank you for the statue which you did me the honour to propose during my pre­ sence here, and which you kindly decreed to erect to me during my absence, I wish first to acquaint you with the reason why I have not been seen by this assembly for a good many days, having betaken myself to the Persian waters, so pleasant to healthy bathers, and so curative to the sick.
tgt_text.6292: For I have made it my resolution thus to submit the whole course of my time to your approval, to whom I have perpetually dedicated myself.
tgt_text.6293: Never will I do anything, great or small, of which I will not make you cognizant and judges.
tgt_text.6294: That you may know, therefore, why I suddenly disappeared from the sight of this your illustrious assemblage, I will relate an almost parallel case of the comic writer, Philemon, as an example of what unforeseen dangers suddenly befal men.
tgt_text.6295: You who know enough of his genius, hear a few words about his death.
tgt_text.6296: Do you wish me to say a few words also about his genius ?
tgt_text.6297: This Philemon was a poet, and a writer of the middle comedy.
tgt_text.6298: He produced pieces for the stage along with Menander, and con­ tended with him, being perhaps inferior to him, but at all events his rival.
tgt_text.6299: For that he was often victorious over him is a shameful thing to tell.
tgt_text.6300: Nevertheless, we find in him much wit;
tgt_text.6306: gravities not quite up to the buskin.

tgt_text.6475: Protagoras was a sophist of very varied knowledge, and ex­ tremely eloquent, as being one of the first inventors of rhe.
tgt_text.6477: He was the fellow-citizen and contemporary of De­ mocritus, the physical philosopher, from whom he derived his knowledge.
tgt_text.6478: They say that this Protagoras stipulated with his disciple, Euathlus, for an inordinate payment upon a whimsical condition, namely, that he should pay him the stated sum if he was successful in the first cause be pleaded before the judges, and not otherwise.
tgt_text.6479: Euathlus, then, who was of a shrewd and cunning turn of mind, having easily learned all the artifices for softening judges and deceiving adversaries, and all the tricks of pleaders, and knowing to his full content what he had desired, began to be unwilling to pay what he had promised, and to cheat his teacher with cunningly-devised ex­ cuses, and for a long time would neither refuse outright nor pay.
tgt_text.6480: At last, Protagoras summoned him before the judges, and stating the condition on which he had undertaken to teach him, propounded this dilemma:
tgt_text.6481: —“ If I gain the cause, you will have to pay the price as cast in judgment;
tgt_text.6482: or, if you gain, you will nevertheless have to pay, as bound by your bar­ gain.
tgt_text.6483: Thus, if you beat me, you fall under the force of the condition;
tgt_text.6484: if you are beaten, you will lie under the decree of the court.
tgt_text.6486: The conclusion appeared to the judges to be cogently and unanswerably made out.
tgt_text.6487: But Euathlus, as a most finished disciple of so subtle a teacher, turned his own dilemma against him.
tgt_text.6488: "If the thing is so," said he, 11 in neither way do I owe what you demand.
tgt_text.6489: For either I gain the cause, and am cleared by the decree of the court, or I am beaten, and then I am discharged by our bargain, according to which, I owe you no payment if I shall have been beaten in this first cause I plead before the judges.
tgt_text.6490: Thus, I am acquitted in every way;
tgt_text.6491: by the verdict if I beat you, by our condition if I am beaten.
tgt_text.6492: "Do not these sophisms, turned against each other, seem to you like burs rolled together by the wind, which stick each other alike by their prickles ?

tgt_text.6514: I have prefaced it with a dialogue likewise in Greek and Latin, the speakers being Sabidius Severus and Julius Persius, men who, with good reason, are the warmest friends to each other, and to you, and to the public weal, and are equals in learning, eloquence, and good feeling;
